Eleni Efthymiou, Karalis, Thodoris Gkonik.a. In cinema participated in short
Film: Party (2016) directed by Thanasis Vasiliadis. The walk (2014) directed
by Christina Fakinou and Boystory (2012)  Thanassis Angelopoulos.
Officialy participated in feature film of Tassos Boulmetis, South (2015).

https://vimeo.com/59338986



Marina Villou







Marina Villou was born in Athens.
She is an animator for theatrical education in groups of children, adolescents
and adults. Since 2008 she has been a founding member and in charge of the
theater group Marmelada. Directs interactive theater and writes plays for
children. Also participates in the performances as an actor. Marina plans and
coordinates training and educational programs for schools, publishers,
bookstores, municipalities and other cultural institutions. Organizes theater
workshops, stories and dramatizations tales and gives seminars to teachers.


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MVSaU_CK8Gk

Christos Dimolikas





Director & writer of Alpha male
Experienced in the artistic and commercial world of the Cinematographic
industry. Worked for the last fifteen years with Greek and multinational
production and advertising companies.
Co Founder on imaginethecity
Athens
Biennale Agora Communication Curating team, commercial curator.
http://www.christosdimolikas.com


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Why we need your contribution  - Γιατί χρειαζόμαστε την συνεισφορά σας.


Up to this point the project has been
solely funded by the director. I must therefore congratulate and thank my
colleagues and friends who have spent time and effort to materialise my vision.
Filmmaking is not only my job, it is the way I communicate with the world. We
are certainly making this film and I sincerely need all the help I can get to
finish it.
Μέχρι στιγμής το project έχει χρηματοδοτηθεί αποκλειστικά από
τον σκηνοθέτη. Για αυτό και νιώθω την ανάγκη να ευχαριστήσω θερμά όλους τους
φίλους και συνεργάτες για την αμέριστη στήριξη και συνεισφορά τους έτσι ώστε να
παραχθεί αυτή η ταινία. Το σινεμά εκτός από δουλειά μου είναι πρωτίστως ο
τρόπος επικοινωνίας μου με τον κόσμο. Η παραγωγή της ταινίας έχει ήδη ξεκινήσει
και ελπίζω στην συμβολή σας που θα βοηθήσει στην ολοκλήρωσή της.


Production costs including: 
- Camera Rental (Ενοικίαση κάμερας και
εξοπλισμού) 
- Food and Transportation 
(Φαγητό και μεταφορές)
- Props (Σκηνογραφία) 
- Music Licensing (Δικαιώματα μουσικής)
- Film Crew Payment
- Composition
- Festival Submission Fees (Έξοδα υποβολής της ταινίας σε Φεστιβάλ)

story:
THE FILM

This Summer UK No 1 Super Bantamweight professional female boxer Marianne Marston will face the toughest test of her career when she steps into the ring to face WBF Super Bantamweight World Champion Gabisile Tshabalala This will be the biggest professional female bout in UK boxing history. It will be the first time that female boxers will be competing to win four titles; If Marianne wins she will become the unified World champion.  For Marianne this is the pinnacle of her career but she has been fighting for the right to fight as a professional female boxer in the UK all her life.

Over the last two years Manray Media has been filming with Marianne and her team capturing her grit and determination to be the best. She has faced stern opposition both inside and outside the ring as she has trail blazed a path for the younger generation of UK women who want to compete professionally in a combat sport. Just look at Ronda Rousey in the US.

WHO WE ARE

Manray Media is now looking to raise completion funding to bring Marianne’s story to the world. The creative team at Manray are film and television professionals who have worked with the world’s leading broadcasters. However, like many within the boxing establishment itself broadcasters feel that female boxing is too niche and won’t attract an audience – we want to prove the opposite. 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

No contribution is too small, a like and a share is as good as any and all contributions will be invested in the film. For every girl who has a sporting dream Marianne Marston is an inspiration

story:
What is: Hartford Is Not Dead ?

Its a documentary series that features the movers and shakers in Hartford, CT!
Help me to create and continue a documentary series highlighting the growth going on within Hartford, CT that the mainstream news overlooks. I want to shine a positive light back on our city and bring what Hartford has to offer!
A Little Bit About Me
  • I'm Josiah Schlee, I'm a 23 year old freelance photo and videographer fresh out of college with a Bachelor of the Arts in Cinema Production. 
  • I originally majored in Electronic Journalism, so combining those two programs (Journalism and Cinema) has made me extremely interested in exploring cultures and subcultures.
  • I am passionate about discovering and investigating the unknown, that sits right under our noses and digging up the stories that everyone else misses.
  • The purpose of this campaign is to raise enough money for me to buy the proper cinematic equipment to produce a product that is of a high enough quality to reach a potentially global audience. I want to show my audience first off, what Hartford has to offer; and eventually show them what cities around the nation and then the world have to offer that the common travel and culture television show overlooks.
  • If my goal is reached the next episode I produce I will be able to pitch to Netlfix, Hulu, Amazon, Yahoo, Vimeo, etc as a marketable and presentable documentary piece.

What Hartford Is Not Dead Needs To Be Produced 

  • The project requires $2,200 to purchase the proper cinematic equipment to produce a piece of film that is globally presentable.
  • The equipment needed is listed in order from most expensive to least expensive.
  • Two Wireless Lavalier Microphone Bodypack+ Transmitters- $570
  • Oscillating Bearing Camera Stabilizer- $190
  • 3 Piece LED Light Kit with Stands- $180
  • Jib Cinema Camera Crane for DSLR's - $160
  • Video Backdrop and Studio Lighting Kit- $160
  • Shotgun Microphone for DSLR- $150
  • Heavy Duty Tripod to Support Jib Crane - $130
  • Handheld Weighted Camera Stabilizer- $120
  • 128GB 1000x mbs Memory Card- $60
  • Light Reflector Kit with Stand+ Sandbag- $40
  • LED DSLR Light Mount- $30
  • Handheld Light Reflectors- $20
  • Tripod Weight Bags to Support Jib Crane- $16
  • Stone Bag to Support Jib Crane -$15
  • Dual Bracket Mount for Mic+ LED Light for DSLR- $12
  • Memory Card Case to Protect Memory Cards- $12
  • Indiegogo Fees- $95
  • Paypal Fees- $95
  • Shipping Fees for Equipment- $110
  • That all rounds out to be a total of $2,200
  • WHAT YOU GET
  • The purchase of all this equipment will allow Hartford Is Not Dead to produce a piece(s) of film that can be marketed to multiple outlets so I can continue to explore and bring to light "the little guys".
  • IF I DON'T RAISE ENOUGH FUNDS THEN WHAT? WELL..
  • If the goal is not reached I will start by purchasing the most expensive items then funding the rest of the money that was not raised with my own money out of pocket so I can make sure production still continues. This will take time for me to save for and afford, delaying the production process.

The Impact

Your contribution will help bring the small artists, chefs, craftsman and creators of all kinds from your home city into the spotlight and show the nation and hopefully the world what they have to offer.

  • Hartford Is Not Dead Episode 1 was released June 15th, 2015 and it inspired me to extend the series and go way beyond the boundaries of Hartford, CT.

Risks & Challenges

It is going to be very difficult to raise this amount of money in only 60 days!

I need to raise $37 each day for 60 days straight for this campaign to be successful.

But, if we all team up this can easily be done! Let me put it this way for you.

If every one of my Facebook friends (630) donated $3.50 just once the campaign goal would be reached in ONE DAY!

If you share this with your friends and family, and anyone who may be interested this goal could be reached so easily.

If you donated $5 a week for each of the 8 weeks total this campaign runs. I would only need 55 people to make that commitment. 

This can be done! Every dollar, every penny counts and is so much appreciated!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you are not able to contribute I would greatly appreciate you sharing this campaign page around all possible outlets you can think of, lets do this!

story:
Mission Statement

The Red Room is a Psychological Thriller film about an aspiring young writer (Nia) who lands her dream job as a writing assistant to her favorite novelist, and uncovers a terrifying secret. The sub-plot is about finding your voice in an era of underrepresentation and inclusion.

As a filmmaker, my goal is to tell compelling artistic stories that not only entertain but also shed light on different perspectives/issues. Having the ability to tell stories for the underrepresented communities in all genres whether science-fiction, horror, fantasy, drama, action, comedy, or in this case THRILLER.

About The Project

THE STORY

When an aspiring writer is offered a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity as a writing assistant to her favorite novelist, she agrees to spend a weekend with the eccentric novelist and his wife, but it quickly turns into a deadly game of cat and mouse due to the novelist's unconventional writing process.  

Get to Know Us

Cast

Aleigh Burt: Playing the role of "Nia". 

"My name is Aleigha Burt, and I’ve been cast as Nia in the movie, “The Red Room.” I’m an actress based out of Atlanta, GA, and I love to travel, EAT and binge-watch anything created by the true QUEEN, Shonda Rhimes. I’m so excited to be playing in my first thriller, and I can’t wait to get started on this project!”

Mark Phialas: Playing the role of "Jacob"

" I’ve been captivated with stories most of my life, whether they be revealed on a stage, a film set, a football stadium, a basketball arena, or something as simple as old friends running into each other in a park, both with tales to share. I’m passionate about the process of that telling, as each story has its own parameters, it's own “recipe” that brings the cake to the table, so to speak. Thrilled to be granted the opportunity to be part of the collaborative undertaking of THE RED ROOM. It's going to be a heck of a ride."

Clesete: Playing "Jennifer Rory"

Born and raised in South Carolina as one of seven kids, I navigated to North Carolina for my college years, with a degree in Drama/Theatre Arts and English/Literature. I spent many years focusing on live theatre before navigating towards film and commercial work. My quirky sense of humor led me to get up in front of the class as far back as elementary school to “act” during oral presentations and reports I had to present – and showed me how much I enjoyed it! Performing allows me to explore the lives of different people in various situations and relationships. I cannot be more excited and thankful to work with this talented group of cast and crew.

Erycka Anderson: Playing the Role of "Dee"

"I'm a fun and very sarcastic person and I love showcasing a good vibe for the people I'm around. I'm excited for the audience to be pulled into this rollercoaster of a ride on The Red Room. Truly a masterpiece and will have you on the edge of your seat."

Tatianna Blount: Playing the role of "Alexandria."

"NC native with a passion for cinema and film production. Free-spirited, slightly offbeat, and love to laugh. Super excited about getting on set! I love to learn and welcome taking direction. Beyond ecstatic to see what the crew is going to pull out of every member of the cast."

Crew

Director/Writer: Marquis Wallace

Line Producer Charlee Moss

Supervising producer: Devon Gulati

Associate Producer: Nahomy Gonzalaz

Post Producer: Jinell Web

DP: Braxton Langston

Sound: Chris Meadows

PA/AC: Gabrielle Joseph

 

 

When

Production begins September 13th Ending on October 1st. Ambitious Right?!? However, WE truly believe we can make it happen with your help. 

What We Need

PURPOSE

We are currently in pre-production.  I have provided upfront costs of $15,000 to lock down the perfect location and make sure our cast is taken care of. However, we need you to help us finish funding production. We need to cover the cost of meals, equipment and rentals, transportation, set design, and most importantly crew. Our goal is to reach $30,000 which is an additional 15k and we need your help to achieve this. Not only will you help in bringing this film to life but you are also helping in pushing the narrative of finding your voice when faced with difficult decisions. Our flex goal is $50,000 but with $30,000, we can go into production and make sure the awesome men and women on this are well-taken care of. 

Crew: $6,000

Meals: $1,000

Equipment Rentals: $4,000

Lighting and Sound Rentals: $3,000

Set Design: $1,000

___________________________

Total: $15,000

 

What You Get | Perks

 

$25 | Perks

  • Social Media Shout Out!

$50 | Perks

  • Special Thanks in Credits

$100 | Perks

  • Special Thanks in Credits!
  • Social Media Shout Out!
  • Movie Poster

$250 | Perks

  • Special Thanks in Credits!
  • Social Media Shout Out!
  • Movie Poster
  • Access to BTS Footage and Photographs

$500

  • Special Thanks in Credits!
  • Social Media Shout Out!
  • Movie Poster 
  • Copy of Film!
  • Access to BTS Footage and Photographs

$1000

  • Special Thanks in Credits!
  • Social Media Shout Out!
  • Movie Poster 
  • Copy of Film!
  • Access to BTS Footage and Photographs
  • Associate Producer Credit
  • Advance Screening Invite

$2500

  • Special Thanks in Credits!
  • Movie Poster 
  • Social Media Shout Out!
  • Copy of Film!
  • Access to BTS Footage and Photographs
  • Associate Producer Credit
  • Advance Screening Invite

$5000

  • Special Thanks in Credits!
  • Social Media Shout Out!
  • Movie Poster 
  • Copy of Film!
  • Access to BTS Footage and Photographs
  • Executive Producer Credit
  • Advance Screening Invite
  • A signed copy of the Script

The Impact

THE SUB-STORY ( "B" PLOT)

In our current day and age, now more than ever, are we finally starting to see the power of inclusion. The different perspectives that we as BIPOC share are not only entertaining but also moving. Being a filmmaker of color, I wanted to be able to tell a riveting tale from our viewpoint, so that it also informs just as much as it entertains. It can be hard trying to find your voice and seeing where you fit in especially in your dream career. Having characters that are relatable helps create an open dialogue that is much needed in today's society. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Share by using the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Donate Props
  • Donate Equipment
  • Provide Meals on Set

ARTISTIC STATEMENT

Filmmaking is an art & stories have the power to change us all. They move us, give us new ideas, empower us, make us laugh or cry. It hits us far differently than the other forms of art by pushing and pulling on our emotions and changing the way we think about certain perspectives and ideas.

PLEASE FOLLOW US AND SHARE THE WORD!

Give us a follow @theredroommve on Instagram & @TheRedRoomMovi1 on Twitter. Share our campaign with your followers! Doing so is tremendously helpful, and it goes a long way to support bringing this film to life. 

We really appreciate the love, support, and encouragement from all of you to help bring this ambitious film together!

THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR CONSIDERING OUR PROJECT

Check out our WEBSITE!

We have a website for you to check out and see more about the film and our updates!

theredroommovie.com

story:
Short Summary

The Campaign

A team of recently graduated student filmmakers are needing YOUR help to share their fully finished award winning film "Inheritance" with the world.

Holly Black - Writer/Director/DP/Editor

My name is Holly Black and I am one of the co-founders of Wolf and Willow Productions. I graduated with a BFA in film from Evangel University in 2020 and have worked as a writer, producer, and director on multiple feature films: "Actress for Hire", "Enigma" and "Led Astray", to name a few. 

 

Kayla Kononiuk - Producer/Assistant Director

Kayla Kononiuk is Wolf and Willow Productions other founder. Kayla has loved to make fun videos with her friends since she was little and that love sent her on a path to become a filmmaker. At Evangel University, she worked as Camera Operator/Grip on the short film “Out of my Mind” and many other projects. 

 

The Synopsis

College drop-out Luke Wheaton is trapped in a fractured family. But when he receives his inheritance he suddenly has the power to make his own path. Lured by a pretty face and the promise of winning big Luke journeys with his friends to find his future. But things are not what they seem. A criminal with a dark secret has just been released and is on a mission: one that will change the Wheaton family forever.

 

The Story Behind the Story

I (Holly) have been making movies since seventh grade and I loved the process so much I went to college for it. 2020 was my senior year and I had written my best film yet, a poignant yet dramatic and comedic family drama titled "Inheritance".  Our cast and crew was loaded with talent, it was going to be amazing. 

Then Covid hit. 

At this point we had already filmed half of the movie.  And so much time and energy and heart had gone into production that it seemed like a tragedy to scrap it now.  We decided to push on filming (with lots of Covid precautions) and we were able to receive the finances to finish the film thanks to our amazing community.

Now the film is finished and we need that community again. 

We are giving you a chance to join us on our filmmaking journey as we raise funds to help cover post production and distribution expenses.  Help spread this message of hope with the world! 

 

The Mission

Our goal is to use this film to its full potential and share it with as many people as possible

 

What We Need & What You Get

Funding Breakdown

Festival Fees: $295.00
Music Licensing: $350.00
Editing Software: $400.00
Printing/Shipping DVDs: $500.00
Travel to Festivals: $455.00

TOTAL: $2000.00

What You Get

We have amazing perks planned for our awesome film community!

Thank You ($5)

For those of you that donate $5.00 or more the cast and crew with think warm fuzzy feeling toward you and be ever so grateful. 

Signed Poster ($15)

For those who donate $15.00 or more you will receive a beautiful 8"x 11" Inheritance poster, signed by members of the cast and crew!

Signed DVD ($25)

For those who donate $25.00 or more you will receive the Inheritance DVD in a lovely jewel hard case signed by the cast and crew!

Signed Blu-Ray ($50)

If you are one of the amazingly generous donors who gives $50.00 or more you will receive the Inheritance Blu-ray signed by the cast and crew, and packed full of awesome special features including: Director's commentary ~ Deleted Scenes ~ The Making Of ~ Cast and Crew Interviews ~ Behind the Scenes ~ Photo Gallery ~ Trailer.

 

The Impact

An Important Message

Inheritance is a film that explores the message of forgiveness and reconciliation.  It is a powerful film that has moved people.  At the core of this film is a message that is bigger than the film's creators, and we believe it is our mission to bring that message to the world.  

 

Changing Perceptions

Inheritance also deals with themes of drug addiction, the stereotypes surrounding those who have been incarcerated, and homelessness.  All issues that the world needs to pay attention to.  By sharing Inheritance with the world we believe that we will help raise awareness about these issues and get people to think differently about those who are struggling with addiction, ex-cons, or experiencing homelessness.  We want to help humanize them.  They are not the enemy, they are our brothers and our sisters, and it's time we welcome them home. 

We hope that Inheritance will help start a conversation about how we can better help our brothers and sisters and encourage filmmakers to create movies that matter.

 

Is it good though?

This film has gotten positive feedback during test screening and won "Best Student Feature Film" in the Texas Faith and Family Film Festival, and we are sure you'll like it too.

This is the 6th feature film I (Holly) have worked on.  So I have years of experience crafting compelling stories and creating enjoyable films.

 

Risks & Challenges

The risks associated with this project are low.  If we aren't able to find funding, we will still be able to release Inheritance, but it won't be in DVD and Blu-ray format and we will not be able to reach nearly as many people.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't give financially, that is completely okay.  We still need your help!

Share this campaign on social media (if you would like), and follow us on Facebook and Instagram at Wolf and Willow Productions to stay up to date on Inheritance's festival run and upcoming projects. 

Schedule a showing

If you know of a homeless shelter, community center, church, or reintegration center that would benefit from a showing of Inheritance then please contact Holly Black at WolfandWillowProductions2021@gmail.com to schedule a show date.

I truly appreciate you taking the time to read this.  And, as always, have an awesome day!
story_txt:
Short Summary
The Campaign
A team of recently graduated student filmmakers are needing YOUR help to share their fully finished award winning film "Inheritance" with the world.
Holly Black - Writer/Director/DP/Editor

My name is Holly Black and I am one of the co-founders of Wolf and Willow Productions. I graduated with a BFA in film from Evangel University in 2020 and have worked as a writer, producer, and director on multiple feature films: "Actress for Hire", "Enigma" and "Led Astray", to name a few. 
 
Kayla Kononiuk - Producer/Assistant Director

Kayla Kononiuk is Wolf and Willow Productions other founder. Kayla has loved to make fun videos with her friends since she was little and that love sent her on a path to become a filmmaker. At Evangel University, she worked as Camera Operator/Grip on the short film “Out of my Mind” and many other projects. 
 
The Synopsis
College drop-out Luke Wheaton is trapped in a fractured family. But when he receives his inheritance he suddenly has the power to make his own path. Lured by a pretty face and the promise of winning big Luke journeys with his friends to find his future. But things are not what they seem. A criminal with a dark secret has just been released and is on a mission: one that will change the Wheaton family forever.

story:
Short Summary

Hi I'm Ginger Britt Daniels and I wrote this short female driven cop mystery/drama. I am also producing this film through my GingerPants Productions, and am lead actress in the film. I have been a working actress for over 20 years, and started my production company about 2 years ago. This is my first foray into writing my own script. Here is what it's about: A tortured cop/mother must find the abuser and killer of a young girl with the help of her sister in order to make peace with her troubled past.

I am crowdfunding because we are shooting in the NY/NJ area I cannot imagine making this project without each and every one of the people  involved, so I hope that you can make this dream of mine a reality. It is of the utmost importance that I get this story out to YOU because my story is very close to my heart. The subject deals with child sexual abuse trauma and what that can create in an adult woman. 

You will help us achieve the goal of AWARENESS on this subject, and I am donating a percentage of all money that is donated to us to the National Center on Domestic and Sexual Violence. With your help, we can make a difference. I hope to make that difference with my film, but we need help to make it the very best that it can be. 

To see some of our work:

www.gingerbrittdaniels.com 

Lain Ewing is directing this project: www.lainewing.com

Brandon Haynes is our Cinematographer: www.vimeo.com/bhaynes 

 

What We Need And What You Get

We need $10,000.00 to make this the best short film that we can. The money is going to the expense of shooting on the east coast with a relatively large cast and crew.  

You as a donator to the cause will be helping as I said earlier, REAL SURVIVORS OF CHILD SEXUAL ABUSE. That alone should make you want to help. AND these funds, if we obtain more than our goal, will go to directly to THE NATIONAL CENTER ON DOMESTIC AND SEXUAL VIOLENCE. 

You will also, depending on your pledge, be able to enjoy such perks as having your name in the ending credits, as well as first access to viewing the completed film, AND specialized film merchandise...not to mention access to behind the scenes footage.

The Impact

Again, you could make the difference, no matter how small, in the life of a young girl or boy who has survived unimaginable trauma at the hands of abuse. You are also allowing us to move forward and put our artistic view on the subject matter that could help encourage countless children to be brave enough to come forward and tell their own story, not to mention help them to know that THEY ARE NOT ALONE.

Other Ways You Can Help

If by chance you cannot make a financial contribution, THAT'S OK! We'd love it if you got the word out about our film, and encouraged those that CAN contribute to do so. Spread it around to your friends and followers...anyone that you think might be interested in this important film.

You can easily use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Kevin Fredericks. I'm a creator and comedian with dreams of achieving more. I currently make a daily video and travel the United States performing stand up comedy. 

This project is important to me for three reasons: It is paramount for me to follow my dreams despite AMAZING obstacles hoping to inspire others to do the same in their lives.  It is important to me to give other people the opportunity to follow their dreams. Finally I want to show my children and others that if you set your mind to something and have FAITH in yourself and what God has for you, YOU CAN DO ANYTHING!

What We Need & What You Get

I can do a lot of things on my own including financing this entire comedy tour, however, I cannot film and produce this documentary on my own.  The money raised will be used to pay the director and filmmaker, cover his travel costs, and to hire an editor. 

$5,000 will cover the director who 

$7,500 will cover his travel and lodging

$2,500 will cover an editor.

If we don't reach our goal, all of the money will cover travel and lodging. 

The Impact

The world NEEDS clean content.  We need to inspire our children to be something more than what today's media tells them they should be. They need to see positive examples on their screens. As much as we hate to admit it, TV and movies help shape us. So, help me create something that helps shape our kids to be better. We can do better than what we currently see on TV and in movies. Please help me show that. 

Risks & Challenges

This is a difficult undertaking but I feel in my heart its important. With your help I know it can be done. Based on how much we raise its going to determine how much of the tour he can document. The more we raise the more active he can be. He can come to all the dates. If we don't raise enough there is a chance it is only part of the story. I know we can do it. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Look, money is tight. I know it because I've been there. If you can't donate, please SHARE! Tell a friend, tweet about it on Twitter, post it on Instagram and Facebook - all of it helps!!! Share your favorite videos of mine to show people that the world can use this CONTENT!

Thank you in advance for your help and contribution in providing positive and uplifting entertainment.

story:
Short Summary

The story revolves around Richard Sifkitz who after losing his wife is told by his doctor that he needs to start exercising or he will suffer severe health issues. So decides to set up a stationary Bike in his basement to exercise. Richard imagines himself travelling across country however over time with his addiction to the bike so starts the the nightmarish visions and the belief he is being followed by a mysterious figure. 

Like any adaptation not everything will be true to the source material however I tried to keep true and add my own voice to this story. I understand the weight of responsibility and respect I must give to this project however I believe with your help I can make something that I will be proud of and more importantly be an enjoyable watch for you the viewers.  

What We Need & What You Get

For our project we will need £2000 pounds, now this may seem like a lot of money and it is however to make our project true and bring the best out of the source material. The budget will be broken down to the list below. 

  • Actors (Leads, Extras, Etc)
  • Crew (Director of Photography, First assistant director, Gaffer, Editor, Sound Designer)
  • Location
  • Transport
  • Catering
  • Props
  • Costumes

The Impact

I first read Stephen King when I was Ten years of age and he captivated me instantly. I watched my first adaptation of his work at Eleven which one might have imagined may have not been the most appropriate age however he inspired me to be who I am today. I picked up the camera soon after this film and started making my own and I haven’t stopped nearly ten years later. I first read ‘Stationary Bike’ unexpectedly at seventeen where I was gifted the just after sunset short story collection by my mother the true inspiration of my Stephen King fandom. I instantly imagined myself making this film very much the way Richard imagined himself along the highway. Visually and vividly. I wrote the first draft when I was Eighteen and continued to work at it over the years until my final year of university where I saw the chance to make this obsession truly realised.

Risks & Challenges

We intend to run this production professionally, and will need the right equipment to make that happen. While this will be a huge benefit to us, the more resources we have at our disposal, the higher the risk of expensive malfunctions or errors. We have had training in all areas of films and have been preparing for any problem that comes our way over the past three years. There is of course no way for us to guarantee that problems will not arise, but we can absolutely promise you that we will be able to overcome any challenges we are faced with, myself and my team are the most determined group of people you will ever meet. We are not like most campaigns if we don't reach our goal, we will have to work as a team to raise the remaining funds however if we make more instead of putting it on the film we will give it to charity of our choice. We want to ensure that nothing goes to waste and that everything runs as smoothly as possible, and that's why your contribution is so important. With you, we will never feel like we are alone on this journey. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that giving money is hard on people and we understand if you want to help however financially you cant. We don't want you to think that you're any less part of the team. Just sharing our campaign, liking our posts and spreading the word that our project maybe worth a shot that is all we could ever ask for. As every filmmaker knows, it is a collaborative process and no one person is any less important than the other. 

Share us on all social media platforms and follow us on Instagram, Twitter and Facebook. Share to your friends and families. Together we can do this as Stephen King said when making or writing you can, you should and if you're brave enough to start you will. 

"Stationary Bike" © (November 2008) Stephen King 
          Used by Permission.   All rights reserved.

story:
What if you could know "the one?" Today. And all it would take is a quick peek at your phone and a sample of your DNA. Sounds pretty simple and exciting - maybe a little terrifying that they'd get all your secrets? Well, before you go signing up for this entirely fictional service, be aware that it would also mean that your soul-mate could be anyone, even someone you've broken up with. If you're a match, you're a match. For better or for worse, as they say.

This is a future that is not too far away from our current reality, which we know is already fraught with swiping, pages-long match-making quizzes, and DNA panels pinpointing the hormones that make us compatible with others. Intense. Looks like the need for connection is high? We think so too. That's why we're telling this story. 

In our world full of masks and walls, when do we let someone in to know all of us? At what point are we fully honest and vulnerable? In developing this story, the idea of two people who knew each other and had a deep relationship but still had secrets they couldn't share struck a deep chord in us. It's human to want to hide parts of us that could hurt someone we love, could hurt us if spoken aloud, or could bring about a painful rejection. Through Linked, we are exploring the courage and honesty needed to pursue a relationship, even when all the guesswork has been taken out of the equation. 

We hope that this story resonates with you and that you'll join us on our journey bringing it to life! Let's all take a look at how we connect with one another, shall we??

We wish art could be totally free and that things like cameras and sound equipment didn't cost money, but they really do, especially when you want to make the art look and sound good. So, with that...Here are the details, folks!

Your donations will go directly to:

  • Production equipment (camera, sound, lighting)
  • Cast and Crew 
  • Post-production (editing, sound mixing, colorists, original score)
  • Film Festival Submissions

**For anything past our projected goal ($21,000), we will donate 50% to the Endometriosis Foundation of America. 

1 in every 10 women struggle with endometriosis. That's a lot. So often, it is such a private struggle that even doctors and medical practitioners have a hard time diagnosing it, which is probably why it takes about 7.5 years from the first time a woman begins experiencing symptoms for her to be diagnosed. 

We're not making a PSA piece. There are wonderful documentaries that have already been made that share the specifics of this condition (Check out Endo What). Moreover, the experiences with endometriosis are wide and varied, ranging from moderate to severe, so we can't possibly give a complete picture of this disease in a 30-minute short film.

We believe in telling a story about the vulnerability necessary to pursue love, something that is universal. BUT! If we can also represent a population of people who live out their lives with a condition that daily asks them to contend with their own identity and femininity in relationship to others...well, we think that would be best of all.

With your help, Linked will show that we are much more than our physical circumstances and that human connection runs much deeper. (Get it? We're more!)

We're up against a few obstacles in making this a reality.

While our production company is based out of New York City, we are going back to our roots to film in Los Angeles. This is great because of the network we have out there from our days at USC, but also travel makes everything complicated. Everything will need to be planned meticulously, and we will need our team in LA to have everything squared away before beginning in March.   

This is also our first time making a film of this length. A short film can sometimes be anything from 3 to 40 minutes, so we're leaning into the narrative and giving this the space that it needs, which is 30 minutes. With a longer script, multiple locations, and complex shot sequences, this will be a challenging shoot. 

Not to mention the subject matter that we want to give the care that it deserves. 

With that said, we have a great team and we are ready to face these challenges head on, and we are confident, that furnished with your donations, Linked will succeed! 

Here's the deal, we know that sometimes a monetary donation is just not in the cards. Boy, do we understand that. If that describes you, and if you feel excited by the story and the cause, we'd love it if you would:

  • Follow us on our journey: @linkedsoulmate (Instagram & Twitter)
  • Give us a shout on your social media! Believe us, when you're Linked in five or ten years, that's gonna look real good for your soul-mate. They'll be all, "Look how involved they are in their artistic community!"
  • Tell us your story. Reach out and let us know if you've ever struggled with these issues before. We want our story to align with those we seek to represent. With chronic conditions, not only endometriosis, there can be a pervasive feeling like it must be a private experience, like it is too much to ask other people to hold. We want to give you a platform to speak about it. So please tell us. Hopefully our work will be textured with your voices and your stories.  
  • Connect us! You're not in the market for a short film, but you know someone who might be?  Or know of an organization serving the endometriosis community? We'd love to meet them! 

Thanks again! 

- Peter Mitchell and Jennifer Zahlit
story_txt:
What if you could know "the one?" Today. And all it would take is a quick peek at your phone and a sample of your DNA. Sounds pretty simple and exciting - maybe a little terrifying that they'd get all your secrets? Well, before you go signing up for this entirely fictional service, be aware that it would also mean that your soul-mate could be anyone, even someone you've broken up with. If you're a match, you're a match. For better or for worse, as they say.
This is a future that is not too far away from our current reality, which we know is already fraught with swiping, pages-long match-making quizzes, and DNA panels pinpointing the hormones that make us compatible with others. Intense. Looks like the need for connection is high? We think so too. That's why we're telling this story. 
In our world full of masks and walls, when do we let someone in to know all of us? At what point are we fully honest and vulnerable? In developing this story, the idea of two people who knew each other and had a deep relationship but still had secrets they couldn't share struck a deep chord in us. It's human to want to hide parts of us that could hurt someone we love, could hurt us if spoken aloud, or could bring about a painful rejection. Through Linked, we are exploring the courage and honesty needed to pursue a relationship, even when all the guesswork has been taken out of the equation. 
We hope that this story resonates with you and that you'll join us on our journey bringing it to life! Let's all take a look at how we connect with one another, shall we??


We wish art could be totally free and that things like cameras and sound equipment didn't cost money, but they really do, especially when you want to make the art look and sound good. So, with that...Here are the details, folks!
Your donations will go directly to:

Production equipment (camera, sound, lighting)
Cast and Crew 
Post-production (editing, sound mixing, colorists, original score)
Film Festival Submissions

**For anything past our projected goal ($21,000), we will donate 50% to the Endometriosis Foundation of America. 


1 in every 10 women struggle with endometriosis. That's a lot. So often, it is such a private struggle that even doctors and medical practitioners have a hard time diagnosing it, which is probably why it takes about 7.5 years from the first time a woman begins experiencing symptoms for her to be diagnosed. 
We're not making a PSA piece. There are wonderful documentaries that have already been made that share the specifics of this condition (Check out Endo What). Moreover, the experiences with endometriosis are wide and varied, ranging from moderate to severe, so we can't possibly give a complete picture of this disease in a 30-minute short film.
We believe in telling a story about the vulnerability necessary to pursue love, something that is universal. BUT! If we can also represent a population of people who live out their lives with a condition that daily asks them to contend with their own identity and femininity in relationship to others...well, we think that would be best of all.
With your help, Linked will show that we are much more than our physical circumstances and that human connection runs much deeper. (Get it? We're more!)


We're up against a few obstacles in making this a reality.
While our production company is based out of New York City, we are going back to our roots to film in Los Angeles. This is great because of the network we have out there from our days at USC, but also travel makes everything complicated. Everything will need to be planned meticulously, and we will need our team in LA to have everything squared away before beginning in March.   
This is also our first time making a film of this length. A short film can sometimes be anything from 3 to 40 minutes, so we're leaning into the narrative and giving this the space that it needs, which is 30 minutes. With a longer script, multiple locations, and complex shot sequences, this will be a challenging shoot. 
Not to mention the subject matter that we want to give the care that it deserves. 
With that said, we have a great team and we are ready to face these challenges head on, and we are confident, that furnished with your donations, Linked will succeed! 

Here's the deal, we know that sometimes a monetary donation is just not in the cards. Boy, do we understand that. If that describes you, and if you feel excited by the story and the cause, we'd love it if you would:

Follow us on our journey: @linkedsoulmate (Instagram & Twitter)
Give us a shout on your social media! Believe us, when you're Linked in five or ten years, that's gonna look real good for your soul-mate. They'll be all, "Look how involved they are in their artistic community!"
Tell us your story. Reach out and let us know if you've ever struggled with these issues before. We want our story to align with those we seek to represent. With chronic conditions, not only endometriosis, there can be a pervasive feeling like it must be a private experience, like it is too much to ask other people to hold. We want to give you a platform to speak about it. So please tell us. Hopefully our work will be textured with your voices and your stories.  
Connect us! You're not in the market for a short film, but you know someone who might be?  Or know of an organization serving the endometriosis community? We'd love to meet them! 

Thanks again! 
- Peter Mitchell and Jennifer Zahlit

story:
Welcome to the Oxbone Forest

Hello and welcome!  We're happy you decided to take the time to check out our campaign.  This is Oxbone.  Oxbone is a short film about a viking brother and sister who are sent to perform a ritual to help their village, but become the victim of a devious druid.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking for a goal of $2,000.
ALL OF THIS MONEY WILL GO DIRECTLY INTO THE FILM.  

The money will be used for:
- Food
- Transportation
- Props
- Wardrobe
- Trailer rental (for restrooms, talent changing area, and food preparation)
- Anything else the film requires!

Some prizes for joining our team include:

- Producer credit on the film
- Signed copy of the script by cast and crew
- Film poster!
- Oxbone T-Shirt!
- Skype call from set!
- Our undying gratitude and thank you!

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!
Even if you can't contribute and join our team, just telling a friend about it helps us out tremendously!  So please, don't be shy.  Spread the word on Oxbone.

 

Thank you so much for visiting our page and we will see you on the big screen!

story:
Two Sneakers in a Bucket

Hello, my name is Angel Rosa and I am the owner and operator of film production company, Hat City Pictures, LLC, based out of the great 'Hat City', Danbury, Connecticut. Hat City Pictures, LLC is a critically-acclaimed collaborative of award-winning multi-media content producers, all with the singular goal of producing the highest quality content, with budgets within reach of reality. Hat City Pictures, LLC is made up of a diverse group of talent with a collective experience of over 20 years in television and film.

Hat City Pictures, LLC has had films screened at reputable film festivals in several states, from New York City to New Haven, and beyond, and featured online on websites such as Fun Size Horror. A short we recently shot, Samuel's Got a Sweet Tooth will be making its festival debut in the city of Philadelphia, PA, this Spring. 
 

In the film, 85-year-old Julia McCosker, is a frail yet feisty widow whose physical and mental pain sometimes gets the better of her. She's not at ALL happy about her new home healthcare nurse, "Rico", and does whatever she can to try to get him replaced. Rob Garcia plays the role of Rico, a Puerto Rican military vet with a rough past, trying to get his life straight. Rico's relationship with his young daughter has gone cold in the aftermath of a bitter divorce. Will Julia prove to be a most unlikely catalyst for healing?

Rudd Anderson is "Peter McCosker", the son of Julia and a man with legal troubles of his own.

We're incredibly honored to have real-life media personality and TV host, Jim Masters, making an in-studio cameo appearance as himself. Jim's been on our talent radar for a couple of years now and is the epitome of class and professionalism. (How's THAT for a big score!!!?)

The lovely Sarah Krate will be making her on-screen debut as an intrepid on-location reporter, accompanied by her tried-and-true cameraman, played by TJ Murphy.

What YOU can do to help us!

The initial production budget funds for "Two Sneakers in a Bucket" has already been guaranteed. What our goal is with this campaign is to raise additional 'headroom' funds, to cover any unanticipated costs, and to provide a fair rate for specialized production and post-production costs. production insurance, and catering for the hard working cast and crew.

We estimate $2,500 should suffice for all of those additional goods and services; leaving us enough wiggle-room for whatever may pop up.

More Bang For the Buck: Production value! Production value! Production Value!!!

Funds that exceed our goal will be used for additional Hat City Pictures, LLC film projects. From dramatic-comedy to nail-biting horror, there's a veritable treasure chest filled with fascinating plots and premises, and we plan to bring them all to life. For that, we're going to need YOUR help again.
 

Tell everyone you know, about Hat City Pictures, LLC!

If you can't help financially right now, you can still help us spread the word! Please be sure to share the Indiegogo campaign page with all of your friends and family. And don't forget to give our Official Facebook page a "Like" at https://www.facebook.com/TwoSneakersInABucket/


On behalf of everyone at Hat City Pictures, LLC, and Team Two Sneakers, thank you so much for your unwavering love, loyalty, and support!!! YOU help make the magic happen!

Good vibes and best wishes to all,

Angel Rosa
Owner and Operator,
Hat City Pictures, LLC

story:
Story

We are in an age where there is a decrease in human contact, where artifial intelligence is being built in Asia to care for patients in retirement houses, where we don't stop to take the time to share a moment with a loved one or even less so, a stranger. The film will show the importance of sharing, of human bond, of using that precious time to connect. It is about choosing life even when it's bleak. 

Caroline, the carer, will learn this through the cheeky wisdom of old Olivia until the ice is broken between the two. As nothing is all black or white, the story will lead the viewer to understand why Caroline built those walls around herself.

'I'm so afraid of losing someone I love that I refuse to love anything' - Jonathan Safran-Foer

How your funding will be used

Every donation will go towards the production of this film, its completion and getting it out into the world. Even the smallest donation is helpful in order to make the film as good as possible and to be able to pay the cast and crew for their hard work.

The money will go towards:

Equipment rental

Location fees

Team salaries and expenses

Props, costumes and set

Post production (editing, colour, sound, music)

Festival fees

Meet the team

Actress - Caroline 

​NATASHA ESTELLE (https://www.spotlight.com/9813-5641-3874)  will play Caroline, the emotionally distant carer who carries a lot on her shoulders. Natasha has been working as an actress since 1989 with TV credits that include 'The Bill', 'Doctors', 'Holby City', 'Eastenders' and 'Ruth Rendell Mysteries'. She graduated from Manchester Met Drama School and went straight onto playing the lead in Sir Peter Hall’s film ‘The Final Passage’ followed by a National Theatre tour of ‘Sparkleshark’.

Actress - Olivia

CAROLYN PERTWEE (https://actors.mandy.com/uk/actor/profile/carol...) will play Olivia, the cheeky patient, full of life, that Caroline looks after. Carolyn is a British actress who, after graduating from RADA, played opposite Vivien Leigh on tour with the Old Vic Company. Her career has spanned over 40 years in TV, Theatre and Film and Carolyn is not only an actress but also a published writer.

Actress - Rosie

NATHALIE FERREIRA will play Rosie, a younger carer looking after someone very dear to Caroline. Nathalie is a French/Portuguese actress who studied acting in Paris, Vancouver and Birmingham. She's acted in several short films and plays and can act in English, French, Spanish and Portuguese.

Actress - Mrs Bates

FRANCESCA COSTA will play Mrs Bates, a character I'll keep secret for the campaign. From Italian descent, Francesca has been performing on stage and in the corporate world and is currently preparing to play Simone De Beauvoir on stage.

Director/writer/producer

​LAETITIA CAZAUX (www.laetitiacazaux.com) is a French native writer-director, camera operator & editor. A graduate of Film Studies in Paris and of a Film Production Masters in Manchester, she has made several short films in both countries. For 8 years, Laetitia has been working in the film industry behind and in front of the camera, networking and gaining insight into feature films, TV dramas and commercials. She likes simple stories focusing on characters and their inner journeys.

Cinematographer

SHAKA AGINA (https://shakaagina.com) is a British/Kenyan cinematographer who started his journey into film at the age of nine. He draws a great amount of inspiration from the collaborative works of Terrence Malick and Emmanuel Lubezski, as well as his own parents, who have been a key pillar in his work. Known for Concordia (2016) and Serial Clean (2016) Shaka continues to pursue new and innovative forms of story telling as a cinematographer.

Other ways you can help

Post on Facebook 

Post on Twitter

Tell your friends

Forward our emails

Thank you for your help!

story:
Why we need your help

The team behind Husband, Ensured, headed by director and writer Gabe Reiss along with producer Jimmy Morrissey, is comprised entirely of Depaul film students who have worked long and hard to see this film come to life. And we are so close to getting there-- we just need a small amount of funding to cover our remaining costs in the post-production phase. You can see these costs outlined below:

To take a closer look at these costs, we have:

An original commissioned score created by composer William Brueggemann, whose other work can be found here.

Film festival entry fees! Yes! We will be submitting Husband, Ensured, once finished, to several local and national film festivals, including the Chicago International Film Festival, Chicago Comedy Film Festival, and the Los Angeles Student Film Festival. We are very proud of this project, and would like for it to be seen by as many people as possible!

And finally, storage costs for the many gigabytes of footage taken over the course of shooting this project. We used top of the line cameras to ensure that this film looked its best-- consequently the cost of hard drives to store this footage increased along with the quality of the video.

As you can see, we are so close to finishing this film and giving it the visibility it deserves! We just need your  help to wrap it up. That's why we're asking you to contribute to our project today, and join the community that has helped make this movie happen.

story:
PLOT

After hearing terrible news, Kyle receives an unexpected visit from his estranged older brother, Adam. The two have not seen or spoken to each other in five years. A very hostile conversation erupts as the two try to come to terms from past aggressions. 

ABOUT THE FILM

Closure is a dark, gritty film, that deals with two individuals who are both lost souls. They are two brothers who have gone their separate ways, and have isolated themselves in this world. This film throws these two characters (who are polar opposites) together. They are adversaries who bring out the worst in each other. They are bound by family loyalty, but fiercely divided by past events. All they have in this world is each other, but they first must settle their grievances. 

It's called Closure because it is the main theme of the film. Will these two brothers find closure with each other? Will they find closure from their past? 

BACKGROUND


I wrote this script five years ago, around April 2013. Originally it was a 40-page pilot that included more characters, more locations, and more drama! At the time, I never intended to bring it to life and I certainly never intended for me to be playing a role in it. I simply wrote it for fun. But over time I kept thinking about this story and there was always one scene in that script that I really enjoyed. I realized that perhaps I could take that one scene out of the script and make a short film out of it. So after adapting the scene further and fine-tuning it to fit the short film format, a 40 page script turned into 15 pages. The original version was way too ambitious for a debut director/writer. On my budget, there was no conceivable way to make it happen. So I changed multiple locations to just one and five other characters were cut from the script to accommodate the new structure. 

This was a very scary, personal film for me. I've never been so vulnerable on a project (behind the scenes or in front). When you're front and center and handling all aspects of production, all eyes are on you. Every move you take, every decision you make, gets criticized and analyzed - and I was not comfortable with that. But over time, I learned to get over it and made the film how I originally saw it. I never diverted from my original vision.  I went through a lot of emotions developing this film. I had good and bad days. My friends became my therapists, as I would speak to them about my frustrations and fears about the project. I ended up having a lot of support, but I was in a very lonely, vulnerable place. It was not a happy time. 

I was absolutely terrified for people to read the script. I've always written things, but I've never allowed people to read my work. It was a horrifying experience. I believed in my work, but I wasn't sure if anyone else would see it the same way. I wasn't sure if anyone was going to understand what I was trying to achieve on paper. But the overall response was really positive, and many parties were really captivated by this project. I was thrilled that this was something people wanted to participate in. There are tiny seeds of truth sprinkled throughout Closure. The majority of the storyline is fiction, but much of the storyline originates from a real experience. I leave it up to the audience to decide which parts are true....

Filming for Closure was shot over two days. Filming commenced on Saturday, June 9, 2018 and ended on Sunday, June 10, 2018. The entire film was shot in Delaware.

WHO'S INVOLVED?

KEVIN AUSTRA (DE) as Adam (Director/Writer/Executive Producer)
Website: www.kevinaustra.com
IMDb: https://www.imdb.com/name/nm5688205/

This is my directorial and screenwriting debut in film. Previously, I have only ever acted in films and theater. I have been acting for 13 years. During that time, I performed in 44 theatrical productions and about 21 short/feature films. Many times when I was on set, I would observe what the director and crew did as they prepared their shots. I learned a lot just by watching and taking notes. For Closure, I may have come to table as a rookie director, but I came with a lot of knowledge of how to navigate. I knew exactly what I wanted, I just wasn't sure what I needed. 

Five years ago, I asked two friends of mine to read the original pilot script. When they were finished, I asked them who their favorite character was. The two unanimously said "Adam." Not only did this surprise me, but it got into my head that Adam could really be a special character. Not just some low-life, over the top, supporting role he was meant to be. 

I would have never gotten the opportunity to play Adam, if this film was directed by anyone else. Adam is a strong, arrogant, dominant character. He is everything I am not. But I am a character actor, and I yearn to play roles that are the complete opposite of who I am. However, this industry often casts you on your look and your personality. Therefore, the only way that I would play Adam is if I directed the film myself. Adam was such a tricky, complex character to play. And I knew exactly what Adam was supposed to be. I knew how he was going to walk, talk, and navigate through the scenes. I don't think I could ever properly communicate what I had in mind for Adam to any other actor. So goes the saying "If you want something done right, do it yourself."

ERIC FRANCIS MELARAGNI (PA) as Kyle
IMDb: https://www.imdb.com/name/nm8318443/

Since Adam was already casted, I held auditions (by video submission) in April 2018 to cast the role of Kyle. I personally invited seven actors to audition for the role. This was a mistake because they all gave excellent performances! They made my job increasingly difficult. But I only had one role to cast. Ultimately, I chose Eric Melaragni. I was really lucky to have Eric onboard for this film. He didn't have to audition. He could have ignored my postings. No one was forcing him or convincing him to be part of the project. But he took a chance on me. His involvement elevated my project to the next level. The film would not be what it is without him. I needed a strong actor to oppose me on screen. I needed someone to hold his own and challenge my character. Kyle had to be the perfect adversary to Adam. This film relied so heavily on performance and Eric delivered on every aspect. His performance is eloquent, subtle, and he carries the film beautifully. I am truly his biggest supporter. Eric and I previously worked on a web series in 2016, but we only shared one scene together. However, there was no dialogue exchanged between our characters. We never interacted. Until then, our paths never really crossed until this project. This was a wonderful opportunity for us to not only finally collaborate, but it allowed for two different styles and backgrounds of acting to come together and brawl! I warned Eric right before we filmed that when the camera rolled I was really gonna come for him, and he accepted that challenge. 

DAVE KRATZ (PA) (Director of Photography)
Website: http://www.davekratzfilms.com
IMDb: https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2274318/

I always told myself, that if I was going to make this film, I would make it the best way possible. I was not willing to move forward settling with mediocre quality. I would rather pull the plug on this production, rather than cheapen its value. Mr. Kratz delivered on everything that I wanted.

I never met Mr. Kratz before this project. He was the only one involved in this film who I have not previously worked with. I was in need of a DP and he responded to a listing that I sent out. We communicated through emails, phone calls, and text messages. But we didn't actually meet until 2 days prior to filming. These types of projects often turn into a collaborative effort and sometimes that can cause artistic differences between individuals. But Mr. Kratz was a constant professional. He never fought me on any of my ideas. He never tried to override my opinions. He never tried to persuade me or shame me into doing a scene differently (yes, there are plenty of people that actually do this). He respected every idea that I had and even contributed some ideas to the film that I never thought about! He was respectful, resourceful, and a true pleasure to work with. 

ROB BIELLO (NJ) (Sound mixer)
IMDb: https://www.imdb.com/name/nm7227596/

I am selfish enough to want the best for my film. When I asked around the local film industry for a good sound mixer, Mr. Biello was always the first person mentioned to me. He came highly acclaimed, so it didn't take much for me to offer him the position. I was so thankful that he agreed to be part of it. I had previously known Rob from an indie film that I participated in, where he also worked as the sound mixer. I was so thankful and honored that someone I knew would be willing to help me out on this project.  I was completely flying blind in the audio department, so there were many questions that I asked Rob, and there was not one question left unanswered. He knows his stuff, he's an awesome guy to work with, and he got the job done. 

JACOB HUNTER (DE) (production assistant)
MAX O'NEILL (DE) (production assistant)
Jake's IMDb: https://www.imdb.com/name/nm8050697/
Max's IMDb: https://www.imdb.com/name/nm9484632/ 

I grouped these two together for a simple reason... I NEEDED Jake and Max! No other words can explain it. I have known Mr. Hunter since 2006 and Mr. O'Neill since 2014.  And as my first endeavor into directing film, I NEEDED people who could just assist me in whatever I needed. I wasn't sure what type of complication I was going to face when filming commenced. And I was stressed out about things that haven't even even happened yet. So I needed people who were reliable and who could just help me out with whatever I needed. Jake was the FIRST person (besides me) to arrive to set. His support and assistance truly lifted a heavy burden off my shoulders. Max was able to help out on our second day of filming. His assistance allowed for filming to progress more quickly. With his help, we were able to get a lot more accomplished, and allowed us to wrap up early on Sunday. 

WHY WE NEED MONEY:


First, I would like to say this, this film costed over $1,200 to make. That money was funded 100% by me. There were no other producers or investors involved in this project. I was very happy with how much we were able to achieve on such an ultra-low budget. But I am not a millionaire and currently there are no plans to ever re-coup this money that was invested. Financially, I have reached my monetary limit. So in order to move forward, we are asking for your support to bring Closure to the audience it deserves! 

For this campaign, we are asking for $5,000. This campaign is a "flexible" goal. What that means is, even if we don't reach $5,000, we will still get the funds that were donated. But we really hope to reach our goal!!!!

ADVERTISING:
Simply just posting on social media about the project only goes so far. You are still limited to a certain number of people that will see it. One way we can speed up the process is by boosting our posts. This would reach a much wider audience. You often see these posts on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram all the time as "Sponsored Posts." These posts cost money. It could range from $10 - $50 a week, depending on how long you want the post to be seen and your target audience, location, etc. And that is only for ONE social media platform.

SOUND & EDITING:
This film is not finished yet. There are plenty of things that I need to fine-tune and polish. That includes color correction and sound. I had hoped to add a musical composition to this film, but all of that requires money for the hardworking artists to create and deliver! 

FESTIVALS:
I am dedicated to get Closure into the film festival market! For many festivals, it costs the production PER CATEGORY to submit. Here's an example of a rundown for one festival.
Consideration for Best Indie - $55
Consideration for Best Cinematography - $55
Consideration for Best Screenplay - $55
Consideration for Best Supporting Actor - $55
Consideration for Best Actor in Indie Film - $55
Consideration for Best Duo - $55
Consideration for Best First Time Screenwriter - $55
Total: $385

Again - these are the prices for just one festival. The cost will vary depending on which festival you submit, and what category you wish to submit for. But these are the numbers we are looking at. We averaged that just 7 festivals alone will run us up to $1,500. 

WHERE THE FUNDS WILL GO, IF WE DON'T REACH OUR GOAL?
Everything this campaign receives (whether it be $50 or $400) will go towards Closure's festival run, completing post-production, and online advertising. We will work as hard as we can to bring Closure to a wider audience. But not every festival is appropriate for every film. If the film completes its festival run and there are still funds left over - they will go towards the next film I make. 

SPECIAL THANKS

This project could not have gotten made without a few special friends that helped pave the way to make this film happen. 
JOHN MORGERA
Mr. Morgera was the first person involved with Closure. He was the first one to read the adapted short film version of the script. He gave me a lot of advice on what I wrote, and indicated areas where it could be stronger. I have never written anything for film before, and he encouraged me to continue onward. He had a lot of involvement in the early stages of production, and I could not have gotten this done without his input.
RAGHAV PERI
Thank God for Raghav! Previously, we have collaborated on two film projects. We work very well together. He became a very valuable consultant when making this film. I reached out to him with several questions during the course of this production, where he gave me tons of advice. If there was ever a time I was suspicious about something or if I had to cross reference anything, he always had an answer for me. He was very encouraging.
DANIEL & BRIANNE MAFFETT
But the biggest thanks of all goes to the Maffett's! There would be no film, if not for Daniel and his lovely wife, Brianne. They offered up their house for the weekend for us to film. I can not thank them enough for their graciousness and generosity. Not only did they offer up their house, but they took extra measures to be out of our way when filming commenced. They were absolutely lovely and I can not thank them enough for what they did for me. 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Some people may want to help, but simply are unable to contribute financially. But that doesn't mean you can't help us out! There are so many ways you can help assist us that is completely FREE!

SOCIAL MEDIA
This is probably the BIGGEST way that you can help us! Please share this link on social media! Facebook, Twitter, MySpace, Instagram, etc. You can use SNAPCHAT and snap a picture of the campaign and send it to all your friends! 
Any of these methods will help this film reach a wider audience and it will gain more publicity. We can achieve more funds by more people finding out about us!

WORD-OF-MOUTH
Some believe that word of mouth is the best publicity! Speak to your friends and family. Engage with them about what we are trying to accomplish here.
story_txt:
PLOT
After hearing terrible news, Kyle receives an unexpected visit from his estranged older brother, Adam. The two have not seen or spoken to each other in five years. A very hostile conversation erupts as the two try to come to terms from past aggressions. 
ABOUT THE FILM
Closure is a dark, gritty film, that deals with two individuals who are both lost souls. They are two brothers who have gone their separate ways, and have isolated themselves in this world. This film throws these two characters (who are polar opposites) together. They are adversaries who bring out the worst in each other. They are bound by family loyalty, but fiercely divided by past events. All they have in this world is each other, but they first must settle their grievances. It's called Closure because it is the main theme of the film. Will these two brothers find closure with each other? Will they find closure from their past? 
BACKGROUND
I wrote this script five years ago, around April 2013. Originally it was a 40-page pilot that included more characters, more locations, and more drama! At the time, I never intended to bring it to life and I certainly never intended for me to be playing a role in it. I simply wrote it for fun. But over time I kept thinking about this story and there was always one scene in that script that I really enjoyed. I realized that perhaps I could take that one scene out of the script and make a short film out of it. So after adapting the scene further and fine-tuning it to fit the short film format, a 40 page script turned into 15 pages. The original version was way too ambitious for a debut director/writer. On my budget, there was no conceivable way to make it happen. So I changed multiple locations to just one and five other characters were cut from the script to accommodate the new structure. This was a very scary, personal film for me. I've never been so vulnerable on a project (behind the scenes or in front). When you're front and center and handling all aspects of production, all eyes are on you. Every move you take, every decision you make, gets criticized and analyzed - and I was not comfortable with that. But over time, I learned to get over it and made the film how I originally saw it. I never diverted from my original vision.  I went through a lot of emotions developing this film. I had good and bad days. My friends became my therapists, as I would speak to them about my frustrations and fears about the project. I ended up having a lot of support, but I was in a very lonely, vulnerable place. It was not a happy time. I was absolutely terrified for people to read the script. I've always written things, but I've never allowed people to read my work. It was a horrifying experience. I believed in my work, but I wasn't sure if anyone else would see it the same way. I wasn't sure if anyone was going to understand what I was trying to achieve on paper. But the overall response was really positive, and many parties were really captivated by this project. I was thrilled that this was something people wanted to participate in. There are tiny seeds of truth sprinkled throughout Closure. The majority of the storyline is fiction, but much of the storyline originates from a real experience. I leave it up to the audience to decide which parts are true....Filming for Closure was shot over two days. Filming commenced on Saturday, June 9, 2018 and ended on Sunday, June 10, 2018. The entire film was shot in Delaware.
WHO'S INVOLVED?
KEVIN AUSTRA (DE) as Adam (Director/Writer/Executive Producer)Website: www.kevinaustra.comIMDb: https://www.imdb.com/name/nm5688205/This is my directorial and screenwriting debut in film. Previously, I have only ever acted in films and theater. I have been acting for 13 years. During that time, I performed in 44 theatrical productions and about 21 short/feature films. Many times when I was on set, I would observe what the director and crew did as they prepared their shots. I learned a lot just by watching and taking notes. For Closure, I may have come to table as a rookie director, but I came with a lot of knowledge of how to navigate. I knew exactly what I wanted, I just wasn't sure what I needed. Five years ago, I asked two friends of mine to read the original pilot script. When they were finished, I asked them who their favorite character was. The two unanimously said "Adam." Not only did this surprise me, but it got into my head that Adam could really be a special character. Not just some low-life, over the top, supporting role he was meant to be. I would have never gotten the opportunity to play Adam, if this film was directed by anyone else. Adam is a strong, arrogant, dominant character. He is everything I am not. But I am a character actor, and I yearn to play roles that are the complete opposite of who I am. However, this industry often casts you on your look and your personality. Therefore, the only way that I would play Adam is if I directed the film myself. Adam was such a tricky, complex character to play. And I knew exactly what Adam was supposed to be. I knew how he was going to walk, talk, and navigate through the scenes. I don't think I could ever properly communicate what I had in mind for Adam to any other actor. So goes the saying "If you want something done right, do it yourself."ERIC FRANCIS MELARAGNI (PA) as KyleIMDb: https://www.imdb.com/name/nm8318443/
Since Adam was already casted, I held auditions (by video submission) in April 2018 to cast the role of Kyle. I personally invited seven actors to audition for the role. This was a mistake because they all gave excellent performances! They made my job increasingly difficult. But I only had one role to cast. Ultimately, I chose Eric Melaragni. I was really lucky to have Eric onboard for this film. He didn't have to audition. He could have ignored my postings. No one was forcing him or convincing him to be part of the project. But he took a chance on me. His involvement elevated my project to the next level. The film would not be what it is without him. I needed a strong actor to oppose me on screen. I needed someone to hold his own and challenge my character. Kyle had to be the perfect adversary to Adam. This film relied so heavily on performance and Eric delivered on every aspect. His performance is eloquent, subtle, and he carries the film beautifully. I am truly his biggest supporter. Eric and I previously worked on a web series in 2016, but we only shared one scene together. However, there was no dialogue exchanged between our characters. We never interacted. No other words can explain it. I wasn't sure what type of complication I was going to face when filming commenced. Jake was the FIRST person (besides me) to arrive to set. His support and assistance truly lifted a heavy burden off my shoulders. Max was able to help out on our second day of filming. His assistance allowed for filming to progress more quickly. With his help, we were able to get a lot more accomplished, and allowed us to wrap up early on Sunday. 

WHY WE NEED MONEY:
First, I would like to say this, this film costed over $1,200 to make. That money was funded 100% by me. There were no other producers or investors involved in this project. I was very happy with how much we were able to achieve on such an ultra-low budget. But I am not a millionaire and currently there are no plans to ever re-coup this money that was invested. These posts cost money. It could range from $10 - $50 a week, depending on how long you want the post to be seen and your target audience, location, etc. And that is only for ONE social media platform.
SOUND & EDITING:This film is not finished yet. There are plenty of things that I need to fine-tune and polish. That includes color correction and sound.
