story:
DIRECTOR’S STATEMENT-

On the summer of 2014 three teenagers were kidnapped by Hamas. The nation got thrown into a race of locating their whereabouts. We reported from their houses, spoke to their families, and tracked the search. We had hope. I had hope. The announcement of their death diminished that. Then the war began and the Israeli army went into Gaza. Then came death. Working in the media, I found myself constantly speaking with families who had just lost their loved ones.

Grief is a hard concept to deal with. In and out of work I would hear of death on both the Israeli and the Palestinian sides. Towards the end of the war the pain affected me. That was when inspiration found its way too. It emerged from the breaking point in which reality seemed incomprehensible and at the same time too familiar. That is how this story was born. Growing up in Israel, I found it inevitable to be influenced by this topic. Dealing with it is my way of attempting to understand it.

I believe that we must always strive for peace, to improve all of our lives and in order to manage to do so we need to keep the conversation going. Films help do that. They create dialogue and make people think and act.

I was fortunate to find amazing collaborators who believe in this film and its message, and who are committed to making it happen.

But in order to achieve all that, I need your help!

Making a film costs money- hiring crew, cast, camera equipment and lights, buying food, paying for locations, renting costumes, props, and the list goes on and on.

All of your contributions will go toward making the film and helping us bring it to life. Each and every pledge of support helps!

 

THE TEAM-

 

ADVA REICHMAN

Writer & Director

Adva Reichman is an Israeli filmmaker born and raised in Israel. She earned her bachelor’s degree in IDC in Israel for communication and business. After her studies, she worked in the news in Israel for 2 years. At the same time, she also worked as a researcher on four documentaries that dealt with terror attacks in Israel. In 2015, she moved to LA to pursue her master’s degree. In fall 2015, Adva became a MFA candidate at the USC, school of cinematic arts, focusing on writing and directing. Today, she is writing a feature about the complexity of the conflict and is working on her thesis film that deals with the same subject.

 

NAHD BASHEIR

Producer

Nahd Bashier is a Druze-Israeli filmmaker and actor. He is a graduate of the University of Haifa in Israel for directing and acting as well as theatre studies.  Over the years, Nahd has been a part of several organizations including the Fringe Theatre, the director’s board of the Ministry of Culture and Sport, a member of the Druze and Cherkasy culture committee and severed as an artistic director in the Kafron Theatre. He directed, wrote and acted in countless theatre plays, TV shows and films. While pursuing his career in the industry, he has won awards such as Best Actor, Best Play and Best Innovative Work. Nahd recently wrote and is starring in a new television show called Dr. Garage which will air in the summer of 2018.    

 

NICHOLAS BENJAMIN

Producer

Nick is an American filmmaker who transferred into USC in 2016. He is a Cinema & Media Studies Major with an emphasis in Film and Television Production. While writing and directing short projects on the side, Nick started producing in a class called Single Camera Television Dramatic Pilot, where he produced a pilot called 3rd Ward. From there, he went on to produce other projects including a Virtual Reality project under USC for the Jaunt Virtual Reality Program called Theatre in the Round about an out of control movie set taking place in the 1960s. Nick recently wrapped producing a Sloan Grant project called Under Darkness last summer about a Holocaust survivor who was forced to take pictures for the Germans until eventually joining the Soviet army. He recently finished producing a USC graduate thesis titled Here & Beyond and is slated to produce other shorts in the near future.

 

NAMI MELUMAD

Composer

Nami Melumad is a LA based composer, originally from Israel. Her credits include over 100 narrative and documentary films, TV series & theater productions. In 2017 she was nominated for a Hollywood-Music-In-Media award for This Day Forward (Best Indie Feature Score) and won Best Score (Short) at Fimucite, the Tenerife international film-music festival. Her works have been performed by the Hollywood Chamber Orchestra, Haifa Symphony Orchestra, The Israel Sinfonietta Beer Sheva and Helix Collective Ensemble. She is a graduate of the highly rigorous Scoring for Motion Pictures and TV program (SMPTV) at the University of Southern California, and holds a B.A. in multi-style composition from the Jerusalem Academy of Music. Nami is an alumna of the prestigious ASCAP Film Scoring workshop (16').

He recently finished producing a USC graduate thesis titled Here & Beyond and is slated to produce other shorts in the near future. NAMI MELUMADComposerNami Melumad is a LA based composer, originally from Israel. Her credits include over 100 narrative and documentary films, TV series & theater productions. In 2017 she was nominated for a Hollywood-Music-In-Media award for This Day Forward (Best Indie Feature Score) and won Best Score (Short) at Fimucite, the Tenerife international film-music festival. Her works have been performed by the Hollywood Chamber Orchestra, Haifa Symphony Orchestra, The Israel Sinfonietta Beer Sheva and Helix Collective Ensemble. She is a graduate of the highly rigorous Scoring for Motion Pictures and TV program (SMPTV) at the University of Southern California, and holds a B.A. in multi-style composition from the Jerusalem Academy of Music. Nami is an alumna of the prestigious ASCAP Film Scoring workshop (16').

story:
GHOSTHOUSE (2018)

Based on the 1988 cult-classic by Director Umberto Lenzi (Cannibal Ferox, Spasmo), this 2018 remake follows a group of college kids who trace the origins of a mysterious television broadcast to a secluded old house in the woods. Ectoplasm pits, flying objects, ghostly apparitions and the Grim Reaper himself are just a few of the horrors that await them inside. 

  • Remake of popular cult classic film, recently released to Blu-Ray by Shout! Factory
  • From the Director of "Nemesis 5" and Editor of "Sleepaway Camp IV"
  • Filming in original locations
  • Set to star Paul Taylor ("Pinhead" in "Hellraiser: Judgment") as the "Grim Reaper"
  • Special F/X by Award-winning artist Joe Castro ("Wishmaster 3 & 4", "Night of The Demons 3", "Blood Feast 2")
  • Music by Justin Apone ("The Toolbox Murders 2")

What We Need

  • $50,000 to cover all initial costs needed to begin production
  • Awareness on social media platforms and within the Horror community

Risks & Challenges

While we already have private investors on board, we still need the funding for our upfront costs. Because we obtained the rights and have some initial budget, the film is moving forward this August despite what is raised here. However, anything we can gather from fans and supporters will allow for bigger Horror genre actors and more spectacular special F/X. This means there is virtually no risk with your donation, as it is guaranteed to help fund a film already in pre-production.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't afford a donation, please help spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Snap Chat!
  • If you run a Horror movie website or blog, please share our campaign to maximize awareness within the community!

story:
Mi nombre es Alexmir Dordelly, soy fundador de la casa productora Mysterious Films, la cual esta encargada de producir mi Opera Prima llamada Examen Final, soy Productor y Director de profesión. 

Examen Final es un guión que empece a escribir a finales del año 2011 y con cada año de escritura fue tomando forma y creciendo en su desarrollo dramático, es una historia centrada en un grupo de chicos que tienen experiencias formadas en sus años de estudio de medicina, y al salir a buscar un fin en común, cada uno vive una experiencia diferente llevándolos a experimentar cualquier cantidad de emociones al borde de sus propios limites. Un guión de mucha oscuridad basado en el suspenso y terror.

Con mas de 20 años de carrera en el mundo audiovisual como director y productor podemos nombrar algunos de mis trabajos.

Comerciales: Teragrip, Montserratina, Movilnet, Chevrolet, Coca Cola, entre otros

Largometrajes Nacionales: Una casa pa Maita, Bambi C4, Bloques, Cuidado con lo que sueñas, Circo Fantasia, Libertador, entre otros.

Largometrajes Internaciones: Hands of Stone, Gold, Joy, Versace, Point Break, entre otros.

También he participado en series de tv, documentales, institucionales, videoclips y mas.

Estoy formando esta campaña para poder recaudar fondos para mi proyecto, la verdad es que se me ha hecho bastante difícil contar con inversión privada por la situación económica y política que vive Venezuela. Por lo tanto creo que es bastante factible abrir esta campaña y pedir el apoyo a personas allegadas a mi por amistad o trabajo y a personas en todo el mundo que quieran colaborar en la realización de Examen Final.

Sin embargo hay que ver el lado positivo de lo que se esta viviendo en Venezuela, y es que por la situación cambiaría que vive mi país, es bastante factible realizar proyectos de grandes magnitudes, la moneda extranjera es un punto a favor y juega un papel importante para la realización del proyecto, ya que incluso podemos decir con certeza que con un presupuesto tan pequeño es casi imposible realizar un proyecto cinematográfico, sin embargo en Venezuela apostamos a que SI se puede.

También cuento con Coproducción Nacional e Internacional de gran importancia.

Los equipos de cámara (Red One), optica, luces y grip, accesorios, monitores, camiones, maquina y planta eléctrica ya los tenemos y están a la espera de comenzar el proyecto.

La Postproducción se realizara en la ciudad de New York, bajo el ojo y el profesionalismo de unos chicos super duros en el arte del montaje y efectos especiales.

La música se realizara en Mexico por el gran compositor y productor musical Ruben Sáez, quien se encargara de todo el montaje sonoro, música original y las atmósferas que acompañaran a toda la película.

El casting esta casi conformado, y entre ellos hay actores de gran renombre tanto nacional como internacional.

Examen Final es una película diferente y bastante original, contada desde diferentes perspectivas. Dejando al espectador queriendo mas.

El monto limite que queremos recaudar es de 37.000$, los fondos van completos a la realización del proyecto, sea reúnan o no en su totalidad.

Este monto cubre:

Preproducción

Rodaje

Postproducción

Cubre la totalidad del proyecto, si llegase a recaudarse en un máximo de 2 meses.

Examen Final es un obra escrita por Alexmir Dordelly, director de obras en corto como “Dos almas un Destino” y “Jugarretas”. Ganador de reconocidos premios y de selección en los festivales del genero (suspenso) mas importantes del mundo.

Es un proyecto cinematográfico inspirado en el terror y suspenso, una producción 100% Independiente, que busca lograr entrar en la palestra de las mejores películas de terror tanto en Latinoamérica como en el resto del mundo.

El suspenso, lo psicológico, lo inverosímil y lo fantástico son la atmosfera que arropara al espectador dejándolo querer ver mas y dejándose atrapar por cada historia. Personajes corrientes de la vida cotidiana que buscan mas allá de sus recursos un fin, sin saber que les depara en un futuro.

El tratamiento cinematográfico según el director, no es nada increíble, mas bien, son personajes comunes y el entorno que los rodea es lo que los conlleva a las acciones. Cada historia lleva su personalidad y atmosfera propia y el ritmo de las secuencias son una montaña rusa de emociones que acompañara al espectador en todo momento.

Examen Final cuenta una historia, donde todos los personajes tienen los mismos intereses y todo conlleva a que vivan experiencias inimaginables, aterradoras y malévolas.

Igualmente explora los sentidos del ser humano, deja al descubierto la sensibilidad y la inocencia de las personas, pero también la maldad, el pasado que se esconde y la debilidad por lo prohibido.

Cada historia tiene su matiz, sus personajes y su atmosfera. Cada historia te atrapara hasta querer cegarte y no ver mas.

Una producción de Mysterious Films y Coproducida por Cinexin Estudios y Pata Negra Rentals. Escrita y Dirigida por Alexmir Dordelly.

 

SINOPSIS

Un grupo de alumnos del ultimo año de Medicina de una reconocida universidad, necesitan para poder graduarse, estudiar cuerpos humanos, la mala noticia es que en la facultad no cuentan con cadáveres para el estudio de la ciencia, lo que los conlleva a buscarlos por ellos mismos y bajo sus propios métodos, sin embargo no están preparados para lo que el destino les depara y todos son obligados a tomar un rumbo que cambiara el destino de sus vidas para siempre. 

 

CREW LIST – EXAMEN FINAL - CONFIRMADOS

 

Director – Alexmir Dordelly

DP: Sergio Castillo "Chichi"

Producción Ejecutiva: Alexmir Dordelly

Productor General – Roberto Navarro

Jefe de Producción – Javier Ávila

Producción: Ernesto Ceballos

Asistente de Dirección:  Sabrina Ruiz

Director de Casting – Guillermo Londoño (USA)

Cámara: José Alirio Rojas (Costa Rica)

Foquista: Jean García

Sonidista: José Luis Rivas

 

 

COPRODUCTORES

 

Música Original: Rubén Sáez (México)

Reconocido músico e ingeniero musical.

 

Pata Negra Rentals (Venezuela) - Equipos de Luces, Grip, Maquina, Cámara, Optica y Planta Eléctrica.

 

Cinexin (New York) Postproducción (Montaje, Corrección de Color,

Edición de sonido, VFX.)    

                                                     

 PRODUCCION

El país escogido para el rodaje será Venezuela, ya que paradógicamente por la situación actual que vive, hace que la rentabilidad de Producción sea muy positiva, tanto que suena increíble para muchos productores de la gran industria. El alza del dólar y la falta de producciones cinematográficas hacen de Venezuela un sueño para todo cineasta.

Venezuela cuenta con la plataforma,  calidad y  profesionalismo necesario  para crear una obra con calidad de exportación, que genere trabajo en el gremio de profesionales y sus salarios sean negociables entre trabajador y la producción ejecutiva, siempre siendo rentable para la producción.

Examen Final es un proyecto cinematográfico que cumplirá con los estándares mas exigentes de las diferentes plataformas que existen en el mundo entero, con esto queremos decir, que no solo se podrá ver en la pantalla grande, si no que podrá ser vista a través de canales Premium, plataformas HD, Televisoras por cable y las nuevas tendencias audiovisuales como lo son las plataformas digitales de Netflix y Amazon TV.

 

Examen Final cuenta con profesionales del cine tanto nacionales como internacionales, por nombrar algunos, tenemos al gran director de Fotografía Venezolano Sergio Castillo mejor conocido como "Chichi", al Camaraman José Alirio Rojas que viene directo desde Costa Rica, a la ex Miss y Reina de Belleza Mundial Irene Esser y al reconocido Director de Casting y Actor Internacional Guillermo Londoño.

Los encargados de la Post-producción, montaje y efectos especiales son los reconocidos chicos de Cinexin, con sede en Madrid y New York, la música original será compuesta por el músico y Técnico Sonoro Rubén Sáez radicado en México y como Coproductores tenemos a la gran familia de Patanegra Rentals, quienes han sido parte fundamental de todo el proceso y desarrollo de Examen Final, contando así con equipos de ultima generación como los son cámaras, grip y maquinas.

Una Producción 100% independiente, con un Dream Team comprometido danto el todo por el todo para lograr una obra maestra del genero.

Una inversión rentable con resultados a poco plazo, proyección internacional y posibles ventas dentro de la gran industria, estudios y distribuidores mas importantes del mundo cinematográfico.

Un verdadero homenaje al culto del terror, una película que dará de que hablar y te hará verla una y otra vez.

story:
After graduating from Columbia College Chicago and moving to LA, Jenna Larson embarks on her first big film, directing and starring in an important and timely film that touches on the internal struggles of accepting oneself.

Callie has always been the poster child for a stable, successful, normal life. She worked extremely hard throughout high school to be accepted to all of her top schools, she excelled in athletics and she was nominated to Prom court. Everyone knows that this girl is really going to go places, but what they don't know is that she is secretly dating Sarah, a girl.

As Callie feels all alone -- facing her inner turmoil of being pulled in two directions -- she must decided whether she goes forward in life after high school as the person her parents and peers want and expect her to be or does she live her truth and face the consequences that would come from such a controversial situation?

DIRECTOR

Jenna Larson is an ambitious filmmaker based in sunny Los Angeles. She graduated from Columbia College Chicago in December 2017 with her Bachelor’s of Arts in Cinema Art + Science with a concentration in directing. Throughout her 2.5 years at Columbia, she worked on over 30 films in various capacities, most often as a 1st AD or Casting Director. Two films Jenna wrote and directed as her thesis projects have over 5 million views combined on her YouTube channel that has over 218,000 subscribers where she posts short films, skits and cinematic content. She is extremely passionate about giving a voice to communities that are underrepresented in film such as women and the LGBTQ+ community, as a bisexual woman herself.

PRODUCER

 

Michelle C. McGhan is originally from San Francisco Bay Area. She is a graduate from Columbia College Chicago studied Cinema Art + Science concentrating in directing, producing, and post production. She has worked on over thirty films at Columbia. She wants to tell a unique story that can resonate with audiences and believes that the representation of minorities like those who are a part of the LGBTQ community need to be shown on screen. Her most recent projects include, Jeong and Among the Hidden, two independent short films about human trafficking. 

 

DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHY

Joe ManHwi Han is a South Korea-born, Director of Photography based in Los Angeles, CA. A culmination of his involvement in music, art, and theater throughout his early years led him to dive into the world of cinema. With his newfound passion for filmmaking, Joe attended Columbia College Chicago, and graduated with a bachelor of arts, concentrating on cinematography.Since then, Joe has worked countless hours with various award-winning directors and clients to bring their vision to the screen.

​PRODUCTION DESIGNER

Robin King is a Boston native, currently working out of Los Angeles with extensive experience in both the film and TV industry. She works as an Art Director for Independent Films, Commercials, and Music Videos.  Having started at an early age with a goal to someday design feature films, King dedicates her time and energy to defining and managing the visual aspects of a film.

EDITOR

Daniel Cassidy graduated from Columbia College Chicago studying Cinema Art + Science focused on producing and post production. After his graduation, he made the move to Los Angeles and currently works as an editor at Jukin Media since October 2016. His love for filmmaking and telling stories is what drives him to want to work in narrative filmmaking. 

It not only takes a village to make a film, but also a lot of money. Your contributions will go directly to paying our locations fees; transportation; the art department which includes: costumes, props, set decoration, building; food for our cast and crew; only to name a few. In order for this film to come to life, we need the funding to make this happen! This is where we need you.

This film is very important and timely, as it is being released during prom season at a time when kids are about to graduate and go out into the world on their own. We want LGBT teens to be able to see this film and carry the themes of living your truth into their own lives as they're about to embark on the rest of their adulthood.

We understand if you can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help stop this problem: 

  • Please share our Indiegogo and get the word out about our film! 
  • Check out and share our Facebook Page - Prom Night
  • Get informed about the LGBT community. The first step to joining any cause is to learn what you can about the problems that occur in the LGBT community.
  • There are a ton of organizations where you can donate like: 
    • LA LGBT Center
    • Gay Center
    • The National LGBT Bar
    • And other amazing organizations can be found here!

She has worked on over thirty films at Columbia. She wants to tell a unique story that can resonate with audiences and believes that the representation of minorities like those who are a part of the LGBTQ community need to be shown on screen. Her most recent projects include, Jeong and Among the Hidden, two independent short films about human trafficking.  DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHYJoe ManHwi Han is a South Korea-born, Director of Photography based in Los Angeles, CA. A culmination of his involvement in music, art, and theater throughout his early years led him to dive into the world of cinema. With his newfound passion for filmmaking, Joe attended Columbia College Chicago, and graduated with a bachelor of arts, concentrating on cinematography.Since then, Joe has worked countless hours with various award-winning directors and clients to bring their vision to the screen.​PRODUCTION DESIGNERRobin King is a Boston native, currently working out of Los Angeles with extensive experience in both the film and TV industry. She works as an Art Director for Independent Films, Commercials, and Music Videos.  Having started at an early age with a goal to someday design feature films, King dedicates her time and energy to defining and managing the visual aspects of a film.EDITORDaniel Cassidy graduated from Columbia College Chicago studying Cinema Art + Science focused on producing and post production. After his graduation, he made the move to Los Angeles and currently works as an editor at Jukin Media since October 2016. His love for filmmaking and telling stories is what drives him to want to work in narrative filmmaking. It not only takes a village to make a film, but also a lot of money. Your contributions will go directly to paying our locations fees; transportation; the art department which includes: costumes, props, set decoration, building; food for our cast and crew; only to name a few. In order for this film to come to life, we need the funding to make this happen! This is where we need you.This film is very important and timely, as it is being released during prom season at a time when kids are about to graduate and go out into the world on their own. We want LGBT teens to be able to see this film and carry the themes of living your truth into their own lives as they're about to embark on the rest of their adulthood.We understand if you can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help stop this problem: 
Please share our Indiegogo and get the word out about our film! 
Check out and share our Facebook Page - Prom Night

Get informed about the LGBT community. The first step to joining any cause is to learn what you can about the problems that occur in the LGBT community.
There are a ton of organizations where you can donate like: 
LA LGBT Center
Gay Center
The National LGBT Bar
And other amazing organizations can be found here!

story:
About Me and My Film

Hello, everyone! My name is Vanessa Leonard. I have had a passion for acting and theatre since my grade and high school years. I took theatre courses in college, and I am grateful that it has continued through my adult life. Acting was my beginning; however, writing and directing are my end game.

I began writing my film in February 2017. I knew what I wanted it to be about, but at first, I had trouble finding a story that hasn't been done before. Finally, a premise came to mind. Once I caught wind and saw the project from start to finish in my head, the words began to flow and everything just simply fell into place.

A Story Worth Living tells the story of Allison Foster and her childhood best friend, Melissa, who find themselves attending the same college in a small Midwestern town. Wanting to end her junior year strong, overachiever Allison receives a class assignment that goes beyond the classroom and encourages her to perceive life in a more positive light.

Coming from a family that has a past of dealing with mental illness, Allison strives to obtain a more optimistic view with the help of her new boyfriend, Jacob Russell. However, Allison's merry shift of focus may be short lived, as she did not foresee what was about to change everything.

From a Journal to a Journey - A Story Worth Living is a fun, witty, adventurous, romantic drama that will bring tears - both happy and sad - to viewers' eyes, inspiring the audience to bring out the best in others while making the most out of their own lives.

The Need

I am raising funds to bring this story to life and here is the breakdown of costs:

  • $3,000 Talent - I have an amazing cast and crew that I'm very excited about. However, with great talent also comes costs.
  • $1,000 Travel - My film requires some travel. We will be traveling to southern Ohio a couple times, Michigan, as well as West Virginia. We will need to take multiple cars, which means multiple expenses (i.e. gas, hotel and turnpike costs).
  • $1,000 Miscellaneous - Food! Everyone loves food. I prefer to make homemade food rather than purchase a quick pizza. I want to show my hardworking cast & crew that I appreciate them so by feeding them well. But food isn't the only thing that falls in this category. I will also need money for props and some wardrobe, as well as FX makeup.
  • $1,000 Post-production - I would like to professionally sound-track this film, as well as purchase music rights to a couple songs.
  • $1,000 Film Festival Submission - My end goal is to submit to as many film festivals as possible. I have already spoken to Sundance, and they have my name along with the name of the film on record.

I have asked for over my goal on Indiegogo, due to the fees.

If my goal is not met, I will gratefully accept what has been given and be the best steward with it and adjusts my costs and budget accordingly.

The Impact

I believe in my project, and I believe in the story. When I gave the script to my casts, many of them were blown away, and I believe you, my contributors, will be, too. I believe this story is important because it breaks the stigma of mental illness.

Risks & Challenges

When it comes to film making, there is always a risk. Whether it's weather, illness or car troubles, there is always a challenge when making a film. However, I am a determined individual, and I will make sure this film comes to fruition.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand not everyone can give financially, that is why there are other ways you can help!

First, you can share this campaign on social media (simply use the Indiegogo share tools!)

Second, like and follow us on social media (Facebook: A Story Worth Living, Instagram: @AStoryWorthLivingMovie, Twitter: @WorthLivingFilm).

The more the name of the film gets out there, the better!

story:
THE HISTORY  

"Ancient Hawaiians believed that water, along with land, belonged only to the gods and therefore could not be owned – not even by the highest ranking ali'i (chief). Water was upheld as an essential source of life and key contributor to the prosperity of the Hawaiian people. The natural resource was so highly revered that the word 'waiwai' was used to indicate abundance or great amounts of wealth... 

Understanding that water directly contributed to a thriving community, people using 'wai' from streams took only what was absolutely necessary. They were expected to share the wai with others. Such practices gave Hawaiians their word for law which is 'kanawai,' or the 'equal sharing of water.' The equal sharing of clean, flowing water provided the foundation from which native Hawaiians were able to maintain flourishing and prosperous communities." 

“From the Mountains to the Sea - Early Hawaiian Life,” by Julie S. Williams 

THE FILM 

The description above — about the equal sharing of wai — lies at the root of a conflict that has played out on Maui for over a century. It’s a conflict that harkens back to the arrival of missionaries in the 1820s, the Great Mahele land apportionment that disrupted the sustainable way of life for Hawaiians in the 1840s and 50s, and the illegal annexation of Hawai’i by the United States in 1898. In many ways, it’s a conflict and history that parallels the colonial enterprise that played out all over the globe. 

Currently, there is not an equal sharing of wai in Hawai’i. There is not a sharing of wealth. Instead, water politics is marked by theft and corruption and a distortion of the legal system, both local and federal. And Maui is ground zero for this conflict. 

In late 2016, Alexander & Baldwin (A&B) ceased production of sugar cane, putting into question the future of over 36,000 acres of land, and the rationale for their water practices — which include diverting millions of gallons per day from East Maui to the central valley, thereby cutting off flow to the many streams and farms along the North Shore. 

This is a local story with global implications. Globally, private companies are scrambling to purchase and consolidate their water holdings, knowing that climate change, environmental degradation and rapid population growth will mean huge profits for whomever controls clean water sources. A&B is no different. There system of ditches and diversions on Maui is the largest private water system in the United States, and they know that controlling the wai is their only means of future viability as a public company beholden to creating wealth for their shareholders... 

But standing across the protest lines and courtrooms are local community leaders, indigenous groups and concerned citizens who are asserting a different vision — one of cooperative ownership, broad public good, solidarity and health for many over profits for the few. This is a vision that harkens back to the ancient conception of shared health and wealth from a practice of sharing the wai. 

KEYS TO THE KINGDOM will be a feature-length documentary that showcases the complexity and drama of this story. At the center will be the individuals on the front lines — those fighting on both sides — as well as the communities that stand to lose or gain from the decisions that must be made. As with Standing Rock, the world will be watching. Once again corporate profit is pitted against the well-being of the everyman and woman, and their children and grandchildren.

OUR GOAL 

Thanks to several foundation grants, we've already shot approximately 50 hours of footage for the film, beginning in September of 2017. We are now seeking $50,000 to support ongoing production for the coming 6-8 months. All donations are fully tax-decutible, as we have secured fiscal sponsorship through Media Collective, Inc., a registered 501(c)3. Funds will enable us to accomplish the following: 

  • Continue to shoot 5-7 days per month, documenting ongoing protests, courtroom proceedings, interviews, as well as water rights hearings at the local, state and federal level; 
  • Edit and distribute three short impact films featuring some of our most compelling characters (e.g. Professor Kalekoa Ka'eo of University of Hawaii; family members who have been fighting for years through legal channels to have their water restored to ancestral lands; the young, passionate lawyers of the Native Hawaiian Legal Corporation; a representative from A&B who can share their perspective on the future, etc.). These videos will serve to build our audience, motivate engagement in the upcoming elections, as well as deepen our ongoing conversations with potential broadcast and distribution partners.  
  • We will also seek additional grants and foundation support during this time, as this is a story that is happening in real-time, and may not have a conclusive end for several years. We anticipate our full budget -- to deliver the finished feature documentary to broadcasters, as well as distribute 7-10 short impact films along the way -- to total approximately $350,000. 

THE IMPACT 

There is only one Maui. But there are hundreds of similar stories playing out all over the world. We believe this is one that may demonstrate that citizen engagement can triumph over development, corporate greed and unsustainable agricultural practices. 

As with our past films, we are confident this film will play widely at film festivals, on television and via streaming, and will serve to engage activist communities around the idea that local change can have a global impact. Past films have won awards at film festival all over the world and are/were broadcast by PBS, Sundance Channel, HBO, NetFlix, Amazon, and many others.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP 

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help! Please consider: 

  • Forwarding this campaign to others who might be interested and posting it on your social media feed(s).

story:
Feeding the Hunger…

I’ve always dreamed of being behind the camera. Whether it be fear or poor star alignment, I’ve just never made the leap. No longer. With a great script in hand, it’s time for “ACTION”.

We’ve put together a full production budget, scouted our locations, run down the equipment we need, assembled an incredible cast and crew that are donating their own time to be a part of the project.

Once all is said and done, we'll be hitting the festival circuit…and who knows what can happen from there? You might have been a contributor to an award-winning film. How cool would that be?

Raising the dead…and by dead, we mean budget.

Our completed budget is the $8500 - this is the absolute minimum that we feel we need to put together a production we can be proud of. We've had investors directly fund $4000 of that budget, so we are trying to raise the remainder through this campaign. All funds are going towards production equipment hires, makeup and hairdressing materials, costumes, insurances, permit fees, and post-production studio rental.

If we manage to get enough kind souls to push us past that mark, we will parse that out to our cast and crew so they get a little return on all their efforts.

“But what happens if you don’t reach your goal?” While getting together all of the necessary funds would be a dream come true, if we cannot reach the goal of $4500, we will push forward and shave costs where we can to ensure this production happens. I'm too excited and have too many talented folks on deck to not chase the dream.

“PERK” up your ears.

We know that everyone who donates does so out of the kindness of their hearts, but why walk away empty handed? From production prints, original storyboard artwork, exclusive viewings, digital copies of the finished film, producer credits; it’s too many to name. Heck, if you are in the area, we will even “zombify” one generous contributor for a "meaty" role in the film! That’s right, we’ll put you in the chair, gore you up, and let you take a bite out of a human. We’ll keep throwing new perks up over the course of the campaign, so keep checking back.

Taking our cinematic virginity.

So many excellent filmmakers have managed to get their first film made thanks to crowdfunding and we want to carry on that tradition. Many of our cast and crew have worked in and around films previously, but none of us have involved ourselves to such a degree. We are finally getting a chance to spread our wings…and who knows what it could lead to? More films? Bigger budgets? Opportunities for work in larger films? Really, the sky is the limit.

But it all starts here, with you getting us off the ground.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone has a few spare bob to toss in the coffers, but we still would love for you spread the word about the campaign, about the film, and maybe you can still get us over the line with a generous donation of your time.

Like our Facebook page @HungerAShortFilm and you can follow production news on Twitter @hunger_short

story:
Where It All Began…

In January of 2015 Bitchpop was born! The goal? A hub for female-driven content that aims to create, promote, and uplift ladies in film. The industry is tricky; if you don't fit the mold, you won't necessarily get the fun roles — so we wrote them for ourselves! In our jam-packed two-and-a-half years, we have completed two seasons of a web series, a mini-series, several short films, an interview series, and sprinkled in a few sketches as well. The most impressive of all? We've self-funded every project except one. (Shout out to Indiegogo for hookin' us up two years ago!)

Our goal now? Get House On the Street made.

In the horror-comedy “House On The Street,” we will take you on a hilarious and horrifying journey as we shine the spotlight on horror’s greatest (and most annoying) overused tropes and clichés. Over the course of one unlucky evening, our five archetypes are thrust into a real-life game of cat-and-mouse. For some reason, they’re on No Face’s hit list… and tonight’s the night he’s coming for them. With a jock, a cheerleader, a brainiac, a loner, and a token hero, the stakes could not be higher — nor more obvious to the characters, and the audience. Come along as we fear and giggle at the House On The Street. Be very afraid… or don’t.

We've mastered the funnies, now we wanna take on the scaries. But all this isn’t free! Turns out blood costs more than lipstick, screams cost more than giggles, and falling-down-stairs scenes are harder than walking up them. With that said, here's where your hard-earned dollars will go towards:

Our cast and crew are working on a volunteer basis — I know, incredible right!? But we'd like to provide them with as many luxuries as possible to make this the best set they've ever been on because happy filmmakers make great movies.

This one is HUGE. The house in "House on the Street" is just as important as all the characters. The problem? Finding the perfect house in very expensive Vancouverland. A large portion of our budget will be allotted to finding the perfect location and finding proper accommodation solutions for its permanent residents. 

To maintain our standards (and to compete with other festival worthy shorts), we will be renting the best quality camera (RED, Sony, or Alexa) for the course of our two night shoot. With it, we need snazzy lenses that can film during the darkest of nights, and insurance (of course) for the camera and crew. We also need lighting so that the cameras, because what is a horror film without dramatic lighting and fog machines?! Your dolla-dolla-bills-ya'll will light up our lives.

Sound is one of the most important aspects of a film, your donations will go towards renting sound equipment (boom, wireless mics, etc.) and a sound guy.

Your donations will go towards insuring our set so all actors are safe, and happy!

Food and Beverages! Night shoots are hard... being well fed and caffeinated definitely makes them easier.

Festivals and award show submissions are the easiest way to get noticed on a grander scale. We'd like to get our names out there. We would especially like the world to see how talented — and funny — actors and actresses from Vancouver truly are. There are a million horror related festivals that we cannot wait to submit to.

As this is a character piece, wardrobe for each character will have to be specifically curated to match their stereotype (jock, cheerleader, bookworm, etc.). We'll be hitting Value Village hard, but for those hard to find pieces, we'll need a bit of money to complete the looks.

Horror films are NOTHING without proper make-up and effects. We'll be hiring two MUAs to assist with make-up and significant blood shed. Who knew blood and death was so expensive? NOT US! Which is why having the budget needed to hire the best of the best MUA/FX will help bring our "horredy" to the next level.

Knives, axes, basketballs, and more! The budget for props is reaching new heights. 

Anyone who has made a short/series/film/etc. knows that post-production is where the vacuum shows up to suck up all your money. Your donations will help us pay for audio clips (which can vary from $2–200), editing, graphics, design, sound mixing, social media posts, VFX and advertisements (buying advertisements on Facebook and YouTube increase your view/profit by a very noticeable amount)... and so much more!

We're constantly looking to grow, learn, and expand our knowledge in each project. Tackling horror is entirely new, and scary (hehe) for us. But we know by sprinkling in our knack for comedy, we can hit this one out of the park! Bitchpop needs you!

As we mentioned, we have been pitching this concept for years, but unfortunately have not received funding. So now, we're taking control back. We've been saving for months, but need just a bit more to make this amazing concept a reality. 

No Money? No Problem! Got fingers? Paws? Tails? Feets? Put 'em to use and share this campaign! Because as we all learned in kindergarten, sharing is caring! Here are some posts you can copy+paste or customize on your own

Facebook • I'm ready to support, and see @Bitchpop Productions’s first comedy-horror film House On the Street! Check out the Indiegogo page, spread the word, and donate if you can. Details here:  https://igg.me/at/house-on-the-street #womeninfilm #indiegogo

Twitter • Help @WatchBitchpop make their horredy House On the Street: https://igg.me/at/house-on-the-street #indiegogo #LetsScreamTilWeGiggle
story_txt: Where It All Began…In January of 2015 Bitchpop was born! The goal? A hub for female-driven content that aims to create, promote, and uplift ladies in film. The industry is tricky; if you don't fit the mold, you won't necessarily get the fun roles — so we wrote them for ourselves! In our jam-packed two-and-a-half years, we have completed two seasons of a web series, a mini-series, several short films, an interview series, and sprinkled in a few sketches as well. The most impressive of all? We've self-funded every project except one. (Shout out to Indiegogo for hookin' us up two years ago!)Our goal now? Get House On the Street made.In the horror-comedy “House On The Street,” we will take you on a hilarious and horrifying journey as we shine the spotlight on horror’s greatest (and most annoying) overused tropes and clichés. Over the course of one unlucky evening, our five archetypes are thrust into a real-life game of cat-and-mouse. For some reason, they’re on No Face’s hit list… and tonight’s the night he’s coming for them. With a jock, a cheerleader, a brainiac, a loner, and a token hero, the stakes could not be higher — nor more obvious to the characters, and the audience. Come along as we fear and giggle at the House On The Street. Be very afraid… or don’t.We've mastered the funnies, now we wanna take on the scaries. But all this isn’t free! Turns out blood costs more than lipstick, screams cost more than giggles, and falling-down-stairs scenes are harder than walking up them. With that said, here's where your hard-earned dollars will go towards:Our cast and crew are working on a volunteer basis — I know, incredible right!? But we'd like to provide them with as many luxuries as possible to make this the best set they've ever been on because happy filmmakers make great movies.This one is HUGE. The house in "House on the Street" is just as important as all the characters. The problem? Finding the perfect house in very expensive Vancouverland. A large portion of our budget will be allotted to finding the perfect location and finding proper accommodation solutions for its permanent residents. To maintain our standards (and to compete with other festival worthy shorts), we will be renting the best quality camera (RED, Sony, or Alexa) for the course of our two night shoot. With it, we need snazzy lenses that can film during the darkest of nights, and insurance (of course) for the camera and crew. We also need lighting so that the cameras, because what is a horror film without dramatic lighting and fog machines?! Your dolla-dolla-bills-ya'll will light up our lives.Sound is one of the most important aspects of a film, your donations will go towards renting sound equipment (boom, wireless mics, etc.) and a sound guy.Your donations will go towards insuring our set so all actors are safe, and happy!Food and Beverages! Night shoots are hard... being well fed and caffeinated definitely makes them easier.Festivals and award show submissions are the easiest way to get noticed on a grander scale. We'd like to get our names out there. We would especially like the world to see how talented — and funny — actors and actresses from Vancouver truly are. There are a million horror related festivals that we cannot wait to submit to.As this is a character piece, wardrobe for each character will have to be specifically curated to match their stereotype (jock, cheerleader, bookworm, etc.). We'll be hitting Value Village hard, but for those hard to find pieces, we'll need a bit of money to complete the looks.Horror films are NOTHING without proper make-up and effects. We'll be hiring two MUAs to assist with make-up and significant blood shed. Who knew blood and death was so expensive? NOT US! Which is why having the budget needed to hire the best of the best MUA/FX will help bring our "horredy" to the next level.Knives, axes, basketballs, and more! The budget for props is reaching new heights. Anyone who has made a short/series/film/etc. knows that post-production is where the vacuum shows up to suck up all your money. Your donations will help us pay for audio clips (which can vary from $2–200), editing, graphics, design, sound mixing, social media posts, VFX and advertisements (buying advertisements on Facebook and YouTube increase your view/profit by a very noticeable amount)... and so much more!We're constantly looking to grow, learn, and expand our knowledge in each project. Tackling horror is entirely new, and scary (hehe) for us. But we know by sprinkling in our knack for comedy, we can hit this one out of the park! Bitchpop needs you!As we mentioned, we have been pitching this concept for years, but unfortunately have not received funding. So now, we're taking control back. We've been saving for months, but need just a bit more to make this amazing concept a reality. No Money? No Problem! Got fingers? Paws? Tails? Feets? Put 'em to use and share this campaign! Because as we all learned in kindergarten, sharing is caring! Here are some posts you can copy+paste or customize on your ownFacebook • I'm ready to support, and see @Bitchpop Productions’s first comedy-horror film House On the Street! Check out the Indiegogo page, spread the word, and donate if you can. Details here:  https://igg.me/at/house-on-the-street #womeninfilm #indiegogoTwitter • Help @WatchBitchpop make their horredy House On the Street: https://igg.me/at/house-on-the-street #indiegogo #LetsScreamTilWeGiggle

story:
TAX DEDUCTIBLE DONATIONS

To make a tax deductible donation through our new fiscal sponsorship from The Film Collaborative, CLICK HERE.

Worry not! We will honor all donations through The Film Collaborative with the same perks as through Indiegogo.

 

VERZIONI SHQIP

Kliko Këtu

 

THE MOVIE

LUME is an Albanian woman who lives with her husband, ILIR, and her mother-in-law, REMZIJE, in a Kosovar village. She has lost her only child a decade earlier in the war and is now haunted by night terrors and unable to get pregnant. Desperate for a child, the family abandons modern medicine and seeks a traditional healer who can cure her.

Lume’s visit to a local witch doctor only worsens her situation, as a prescribed animal sacrifice deepens old traumas. The family then goes deeper into debt to send Lume to Kosovo’s most famous healer. He performs an elaborate exorcism and cautions them that the suspicious witch doctor may have cursed Lume with black magic.

Soon Lume is pregnant, hopeful that she will again be a mother. But as the pregnancy progresses, Lume's tormented past and a dark secret come back to haunt her and her unborn baby.

 

A BRIEF HISTORY

In 1999, Antoneta and Sevdije Kastrati were teenagers, surviving the war in Kosovo and the massacres that swept through their village. The two sisters would go on to become an accomplished filmmaking team, with Antoneta as a writer/director and Sevdije as a cinematographer. Together with their American partner and producer, Casey Cooper Johnson, they founded Crossing Bridges Films and have created dozens of documentaries and short narrative films. After the three completed studies at the American Film Institute, their focus has been on fictional storytelling. Zana will be their first feature film collaboration.

 

DIRECTOR’S NOTE

Zana is a fictional story inspired by my own personal tragedy during the Kosovo War, my battle with post-war trauma and nightmares. The question that has stayed with me is how can one become a mother again, when rendered powerless to protect their child.

Post-war Kosovo, while a rapidly modernizing nation, still has one foot rooted in the mystic. In Zana, the shadowy world of dreams and terrors is set against a traditional village mentality, one that lacks the language to address the deep wounds of war, but instead turns to magic for its answers. It‬ ‪is a‬ ‪dark and twisted‬ ‪look at‬ ‪a‬ ‪family and community‬ ‪that prescribes an archaic treatment‬ ‪for a woman suffering from loss. ‬

 

OUR PROGRESS SO FAR

Zana was one of nine projects to participate in the MIDPOINT Feature Launch program for 2017, and was selected for the MIDPOINT Development Award and the Connecting Cottbus Award. 

With the majority of our financing in place from the Kosovo Cinematography Center and the Albanian National Center of Cinematography, along with in-kind support from Panavision and the Municipality of Peja, we are now in full pre-production.

We have attached the talented Adriana Matoshi (Sundance Winner: The Return, Babai) and Astrit Kabashi (Babai, Oscar Nominated: Shok), starring in our movie. We are currently completing casting and will new announcements of new cast members throughout the campaign.

We are putting together a phenomenal crew made up of the most talented film professionals from Kosovo, Macedonia, Albania and the greater South East Europe region.

Finally, we are actively scouting shooting locations in the Peja region where Antoneta and Sevdije grew up. Some exciting location photos to follow.

 

HOW WILL YOUR FUNDING BE USED

With 70% of our budget raised, we are so close to reaching our goal and starting production. With your help, we will be ready to do a winter pre-shoot (in the snow) in January 2018, followed by principal photography in May 2018.

Here’s what your contributions will finance:

  • Equipment to help with our night snow exteriors (heaters, lights, etc.)
  • Practical Special Effects (FX makeup, gunshots, explosions)
  • Animal Wrangler
  • Special Set Design for Dream Sequences
  • Travel for US Crew to Kosovo
  • Post-Production (Color, Sound, Music, VFX, Titles)

 

MEET THE FILMMAKERS

ANTONETA  KASTRATI – Writer/Director 

Antoneta Kastrati is a Los Angeles-based filmmaker from Kosovo. After the war in 1999, she began making films that addressed issues of post-war society. An alum of AFI, she has directed a dozen documentaries and narrative shorts. Her documentary Seeking Magic (2008) explored the real world of mystical healers in Kosovo. Her most recent short She Comes in Spring (2013) premiered at Busan Film Festival. She recently won the Development Award for Zana at the MIDPOINT Feature Launch 2017. 

CASEY COOPER JOHNSON – Co-Writer/Producer

Casey lived for 10 years in post-war Kosovo, producing documentaries the syndicated current affairs show, Life in Kosovo. At AFI, Johnson wrote and directed the short film Unmanned (2011), which screened at AFI Fest and Tribeca. He has participated in the Film Independent Labs and the Rotterdam Lab. He is currently a Creator and EP of the upcoming Oculus VR series, Campfire Creepers and is Co-Director/EP of Urban Nightmares, a new series on the blackpills channel. 

SEVDIJE  KASTRATI – Cinematographer/Co-Producer

Sevdije is the first female DP in her home country, Kosovo. Shooting since 2001, her body of work includes documentaries, TV series and narrative films. In 2011, she completed her master studies in cinematography at AFI. In 2012, her film The Return won Best International Short at Sundance Film Festival. She has shot four feature films, The Spearhead Effect (2016), The Marriage (2017), Cold November (2018) and most recently, Open Door (2018). Sevdije and her sister, Antoneta, have worked together as filmmakers throughout their entire careers.

SHAWN BRONSON - Production Designer

Shawn is a member of the Art Director's Guild in Los Angeles and is a production design alum of AFI. He has served as an assistant art director on large budget Hollywood feature films Terminator: Genisys (2015), The Last With Hunter (2015), Rampage (2018), and TV series Into The Badlands (2015) and Halt & Catch Fire (2016). His first designed feature film Big Significant Things premiered at the 2014 SXSW Film Festival and was distributed by Oscilloscope Films. He has an established relationship with Antoneta and Sevdije, having designed the narrative short, She Comes in Spring (2013).

BESNIK KRAPI - Line Producer

Besnik is a Kosovar producer who line produced the Oscar Nominated short film, Shok (2015), as well as the completed feature film, The Marriage (2017).  He served as Unit Production Manager for the recent feature, Distant Angels (2016). He is Producer of the upcoming feature, Field of Blackbirds and is Co-Producer on the Albanian feature, Open Door. He has participated in the MAIA Workshop and the 2017 EAVE Producers Workshops. 

 

CAST

ADRIANA MATOSHI – Lead Actress “Lume”

Adriana is a rising star actress who first found acclaim with her lead role in The Return, which won the Best International Short Film at Sundance Film Festival 2012. She has since gone on to play unforgettable roles in Babai (2015), which was nominated for consideration in the European Film Awards and the upcoming movies, The Marriage (2017) and Cold November (2018).

 

ASTRIT KABASHI - Supporting Actor “Ilir”

Astrit Kabashi is an established and critically acclaimed Kosovar actor, best known for his award winning lead role in Babai (2015) for which Kabashi won Best Actor at the Munich Film Festival. He also played a supporting role in the Oscar nominated short film Shok (2015). At home, he is well known for his acting and writing on Kosovo’s long running sitcom Our Cafe. 

 

PARTNERS

KOSOVA CINEMATOGRAPHY CENTER (QKK)

QKK, Kosovo’s national film fund, has supported Zana first through a Development Grant of €5,000 in 2015, and most recently a Production Grant of €130,000.  This initial financing from QKK has paved the way for us to gather more support from  neighboring countries and the European film industry.

PANAVISION

Panavision has been providing premier cameras and lenses to the Hollywood movie industry for 60 years. Through their New Filmmaker Grant, Panavision is proud to support the production of Zana with a camera and lens package for the shoot. 

DEPARTMENT OF CULTURE, MUNICIPALITY OF PEJA

The movie will be shot in the Peja region of Kosovo, where Antoneta and Sevdije grew up. The Municipality's Department of Culture has offered logistical support, including accommodation and food for the cast and crew, production vehicles, office space and public locations.

ALBANIAN NATIONAL CENTER OF CINEMATOGRAPHY (Albania)

Albania’s national film fund has selected Zana in its most recent round of financing for Minority Co-production. 

ON FILM PRODUCTION (Albania) – Co-Producer

Owned by producer, Dritan Huqi, On Film Production has produced titles like The Albanian (2010), Amsterdam Express ( 2014) and Distant Angels (2017). Huqi is a member of the European Film Academy and was selected for “Producers on the Move” in 2011.

 

PRODUCTION TIMELINE

November/December 2017

  • Complete Financing
  • Pre-Production

January 2018

  • Shoot Winter Scenes (1 week shoot)

Spring 2018

  • Principal Photography (4 weeks shoot)

Summer/Fall 2018

  • Complete Editorial and Post-Production
  • Attach Sales Company
  • Begin Festival Submissions and Marketing Campaign

Spring/Summer 2019

  • Premiere at A-List Festival
  • Begin Sales and Distribution

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Post on Facebook (@ZanaMovie)

Tell your friends

Forward our emails

Write a blog post

 

FOLLOW US TO GET UPDATES ON ZANA

Subscribe to our Mailing List

Like us on Facebook

Follow us on Instagram

Visit our Zana Website

Visit Crossing Bridges Films Website

 

PAST WORK

Watch She Comes in Spring (2013), Antoneta’s thesis short film from AFI Directing Workshop for Women.

story:
✰ NOTRE DÉMARCHE ✰

CROIX DE BOIS CROIX DE FER est un court-métrage où l’on prend plaisir à revisiter les codes et les symboles des films ayant marqués notre enfance et notre adolescence. C'est avant tout un film féministe et sensible, cherchant à offrir des représentations cinématographiques différentes, revalorisées et inspirantes.

Principalement, nous avions envie d’explorer le thème de l’amitié entre jeunes filles qui est, à notre avis, un sujet régulièrement vidé de sa valeur dans ce type de films. Nous cherchions à l’explorer d’une manière davantage semblable à nos expériences. 

Pour y arriver, il a été primordial de situer la narration du film dans la perspective d’un enfant et de faire confiance à son regard. Pour camper les personnages principaux, nous avons choisi Léa, la soeur de la réalisatrice, ainsi que son groupe d’amies réel. De cette manière, nous croyions que la communication et le partage des expériences en seraient facilités. Il était important pour nous d'offrir un espace de paroles et d’agentivité aux jeunes actrices afin que l'histoire soit modifiée selon leur perspective et leurs expériences.  

 

♜ TRAITEMENT VISUEL ET SONORE ♜

CROIX DE BOIS CROIX DE FER est un court-métrage de fiction au traitement visuel et sonore expérimental d’une durée d’environ 7 minutes. 

Afin de transmettre la vision de la protagoniste, nous voulions que le traitement visuel soit exagérément subjectif. Nous nous sommes permis d’employer des mécanismes visuels déstabilisants et ainsi briser certaines conventions cinématographiques au profit de la traduction du point de vue choisi.  Le traitement visuel du court-métrage est aussi marqué par l’intégration d’effets visuels numériques qui serviront surtout à prolonger les décors et à mettre en scène des effets fantaisistes. 

Le traitement sonore a aussi une place dominante dans notre processus. Nous avons fait appel à la productrice et multi-instrumentiste Ouri, car nous voulions une artiste capable de créer des ambiances sonores fortes, de faire parler les sons sans utiliser les mots, car notre court-métrage n'en présentera aucun. Des effets sonores hétéroclites remplaceront les dialogues classiques. Nous aurons ainsi accès à la sensibilité des personnages par l’entremise d’un langage réinventé et accessible à tous et à toutes. 

 

✿ À PROPOS DE NOUS ✿

❀ Alexandra B Lefebvre - coscénariste et réalisatrice ❀

Alexandra termine un baccalauréat en études littéraires à l'UQÀM à travers duquel elle s'est intéressée à l'écriture scénaristique et aux études féministes. Elle a collaboré avec plusieurs artistes à la réalisation de vidéoclips et à la mise en scène de pièces de théâtres (Québec, Montréal, Taiwan). CROIX DE BOIS CROIX DE FER est son deuxième court-métrage.

❀ Yann Jobin - coscénariste et directeur artistique ❀

Yann est artiste pigiste multidisciplinaire. Parallèlement, il oeuvre en tant que directeur artistique sur des courts-métrages indépendants. Sa pratique combine la photographie et l'infographie. Il a complété en 2016 un baccalauréat en Animation 3D et en design d'effets numériques au NAD (UQÀC) à Montréal.

Ce projet serait impossible sans notre belle équipe (incomplète sur les photos!) pleine de talents et nous tenons à les remercier.

Photographe de plateau : Odile Gagné-Roy

 

♥ COMMENT NOUS UTILISERONS VOTRE

CONTRIBUTION ♥

Nous sommes actuellement à la dernière étape de production. Nous avons terminé le tournage du film en septembre dernier et travaillons actuellement à son montage. Pour continuer, nous avons besoin de votre aide ! Parallèlement au travail d'édition, nous devons entamés la modélisation et les effets spéciaux, la création et le montage sonore, l'étalonnage et puis, finalement, tout ce qui a trait à la publicité et la distribution du film. Plusieurs étapes qui nous restent à franchir pour arriver à vous montrer (enfin!) CROIX DE BOIS CROIX DE FER. Si vous choisissez de nous supporter, votre généreuse contribution sera répartie dans ces différents départements.

En plus de nous aider dans la réalisation de CROIX DE BOIS CROIX DE FER, chaque contribution est liée à un prix incroyable - merci à tous nos collaboratrices et collaborateurs ! Les détails des contreparties disponible se trouvent à droite de la page.

Notre campagne de financement en est une à l'objectif flexible. La totalité de la somme recueillie ira dans la création de notre projet, que notre but soit atteint ou non.

Si votre budget ne vous permet pas de contribuer monétairement, et, malgré tout, vous souhaitez  nous aider, s'il vous plaît, partagez la page de notre projet (d'amour), CROIX DE BOIS CROIX DE FER, sur Facebook ou Instagram.

Si vous désirez faire une donation privée ou si vous avez quelconques ressources à partager ou questions à nous poser, vous pouvez nous écrire à croixdeboiscroixdeferfilm@gmail.com

Chaque sou donné nous aidera à attendre notre but ultime : terminer notre court-métrage et le partager avec vous ! À l'avance nous vous remercions sincèrement pour votre support.

- Alexandra et Yann
story_txt: ✰ NOTRE DÉMARCHE ✰CROIX DE BOIS CROIX DE FER est un court-métrage où l’on prend plaisir à revisiter les codes et les symboles des films ayant marqués notre enfance et notre adolescence. C'est avant tout un film féministe et sensible, cherchant à offrir des représentations cinématographiques différentes, revalorisées et inspirantes.Principalement, nous avions envie d’explorer le thème de l’amitié entre jeunes filles qui est, à notre avis, un sujet régulièrement vidé de sa valeur dans ce type de films. Nous cherchions à l’explorer d’une manière davantage semblable à nos expériences. Pour y arriver, il a été primordial de situer la narration du film dans la perspective d’un enfant et de faire confiance à son regard. Pour camper les personnages principaux, nous avons choisi Léa, la soeur de la réalisatrice, ainsi que son groupe d’amies réel. De cette manière, nous croyions que la communication et le partage des expériences en seraient facilités. Il était important pour nous d'offrir un espace de paroles et d’agentivité aux jeunes actrices afin que l'histoire soit modifiée selon leur perspective et leurs expériences.   ♜ TRAITEMENT VISUEL ET SONORE ♜CROIX DE BOIS CROIX DE FER est un court-métrage de fiction au traitement visuel et sonore expérimental d’une durée d’environ 7 minutes. Afin de transmettre la vision de la protagoniste, nous voulions que le traitement visuel soit exagérément subjectif. Nous nous sommes permis d’employer des mécanismes visuels déstabilisants et ainsi briser certaines conventions cinématographiques au profit de la traduction du point de vue choisi.  Le traitement visuel du court-métrage est aussi marqué par l’intégration d’effets visuels numériques qui serviront surtout à prolonger les décors et à mettre en scène des effets fantaisistes. Le traitement sonore a aussi une place dominante dans notre processus. Nous avons fait appel à la productrice et multi-instrumentiste Ouri, car nous voulions une artiste capable de créer des ambiances sonores fortes, de faire parler les sons sans utiliser les mots, car notre court-métrage n'en présentera aucun. Des effets sonores hétéroclites remplaceront les dialogues classiques. Nous aurons ainsi accès à la sensibilité des personnages par l’entremise d’un langage réinventé et accessible à tous et à toutes.  ✿ À PROPOS DE NOUS ✿❀ Alexandra B Lefebvre - coscénariste et réalisatrice ❀Alexandra termine un baccalauréat en études littéraires à l'UQÀM à travers duquel elle s'est intéressée à l'écriture scénaristique et aux études féministes. Elle a collaboré avec plusieurs artistes à la réalisation de vidéoclips et à la mise en scène de pièces de théâtres (Québec, Montréal, Taiwan). CROIX DE BOIS CROIX DE FER est son deuxième court-métrage.❀ Yann Jobin - coscénariste et directeur artistique ❀Yann est artiste pigiste multidisciplinaire. Parallèlement, il oeuvre en tant que directeur artistique sur des courts-métrages indépendants. Sa pratique combine la photographie et l'infographie. Il a complété en 2016 un baccalauréat en Animation 3D et en design d'effets numériques au NAD (UQÀC) à Montréal.Ce projet serait impossible sans notre belle équipe (incomplète sur les photos!) pleine de talents et nous tenons à les remercier.Photographe de plateau : Odile Gagné-Roy ♥ COMMENT NOUS UTILISERONS VOTRECONTRIBUTION ♥Nous sommes actuellement à la dernière étape de production. Nous avons terminé le tournage du film en septembre dernier et travaillons actuellement à son montage. Pour continuer, nous avons besoin de votre aide ! Parallèlement au travail d'édition, nous devons entamés la modélisation et les effets spéciaux, la création et le montage sonore, l'étalonnage et puis, finalement, tout ce qui a trait à la publicité et la distribution du film. Plusieurs étapes qui nous restent à franchir pour arriver à vous montrer (enfin!) CROIX DE BOIS CROIX DE FER. Si vous choisissez de nous supporter, votre généreuse contribution sera répartie dans ces différents départements.En plus de nous aider dans la réalisation de CROIX DE BOIS CROIX DE FER, chaque contribution est liée à un prix incroyable - merci à tous nos collaboratrices et collaborateurs ! Les détails des contreparties disponible se trouvent à droite de la page.Notre campagne de financement en est une à l'objectif flexible. La totalité de la somme recueillie ira dans la création de notre projet, que notre but soit atteint ou non.Si votre budget ne vous permet pas de contribuer monétairement, et, malgré tout, vous souhaitez  nous aider, s'il vous plaît, partagez la page de notre projet (d'amour), CROIX DE BOIS CROIX DE FER, sur Facebook ou Instagram.Si vous désirez faire une donation privée ou si vous avez quelconques ressources à partager ou questions à nous poser, vous pouvez nous écrire à croixdeboiscroixdeferfilm@gmail.comChaque sou donné nous aidera à attendre notre but ultime : terminer notre court-métrage et le partager avec vous ! À l'avance nous vous remercions sincèrement pour votre support.- Alexandra et Yann

story:
Hello! My name is Ganeesh Genus, and I'm a MFA student at The City College of New York (CCNY), the oldest film program in the United States. I moved to Queens from West Palm Beach, FL in 2013 to attend St. John's University, where I received my B.S. in television and film production.

In 2016, I wrote and directed GOOD MORNING, which was admitted to festivals in New York, Los Angeles, Indiana, Nigeria, Poland, and Spain.

Recently, like most people my age, I've been thinking a lot about who I am and what I want to say. As an artist, especially a black one, we have to be mindful of what we want to say to the world.

KIDS DON'T RIDE BIKES ANYMORE is my most ambitious project yet.In this 15 minute short film, we follow Ant (short for Anthony) and Dana, a young black couple in Queens on their quest to find out if they're expecting an addition to their little family. In this comedic drama, we traverse the lesser traveled borough and discuss themes like gentrification, parenthood, and being working class poor.

 I wrote it 6 months ago, with the idea in mind that we need to show a different side of New York, and the people that live in it. This isn't your typical New York film. You know, Bryant Park, Brooklyn (the new, gentrified parts), and all the other shiny things. We have an amazing cast and crew full of black and brown men and women that can't wait to get started on this!

No contribution is too small. Every penny helps.

All the proceeds will go directly to the film:

  • Locations
  • Lighting and camera equipment
  • Transportation
  • Marketing and distribution
  • Wardrobe and props

If you don't want to donate right now, no worries. In the meantime, you can still help by sharing this campaign with the world! 

If you have any questions or concerns feel free to email me at Ganeesh.genus@gmail.com

CREW:

Writer/Director - Ganeesh E. Genus

This is my third major project, and the longest one I've made so far. I'm very invested in this, as I feel like I've finally found my voice, and the story I want to tell.

https://vimeo.com/ganeeshgenus/reel

Cinematographer - Bryce Riedesel

A true gem. Bryce loves experimenting with framing, composition, and lighting. With more than 6 years of experience under his belt, we're lucky to have him on board.

http://bryceriedesel.com

Grip/Gaffer - LaDawn Manuel

From Cleveland, but residing in the DMV. A recent Howard grad, LaDawn has invaluable experience on set, and having her come on board to assist was a no brainer. 

http://www.ladawnmanuel.net

story:
5 years after world-wide nuclear war, civilization has fallen. Zoe, a survivor, is travelling with Joel, a traumatized dad missing his family. With bands of cannibalistic “Hunters” roaming the land, and other even more dangerous creatures, they’re searching for a reason to keep on living.

Zoe is a woman with a strong fighting spirit. Like most survivors of the nuclear apocalypse, she has lost her family in the disaster. Despite her day-to-day resolve, she develops a grim outlook on the future, and each new encounter will test her mettle and her optimism.

Joel is the self-proclaimed guardian of Zoe, since she saved his life. He is loyal, but he fears loss, and that causes him to put himself at risk to protect Zoe.

We want to make Afterglow the best web series ever. And we need some funding to help us get there- to pay for the makeup artists, digital effects, and sets that we want to create, we are going to need your support! And in return, we are going to give you lots of valuable content and exclusive items. You'll want to get involved with Afterglow now- that way you can say that you knew about us before Afterglow became "the new Walking Dead"!

Creating a web series is not a cheap endeavor, especially one with the scope of Afterglow.

With $65,000, we would have an approximate $5,000 per each episode of 15 mins, and the rest will be covering our marketing budget, trailer production, and pre-production needs.

This $5,000 budget (per episode), which is easily comparable to an equivalent short film budget, would provide us with the basics, such as:

 

-Rental of the filming equipment, including camera, lights & microphones.

-Rental of the locations, including private properties and film studios.

-Hiring make up artists and make up kits to create the effects needed in a world roamed by Hunters. This includes the fake blood used during action sequences, war paints and injuries.

-Collecting the props such as the fake firearms, the melee weapons, and the body parts.

-Creating detailed costumes for the characters and supporting characters.

-Paying for the time in editing suites.

-Having the basic graphical elements (title screen, supporting visual effects and animations, color correction).

-Getting insurance for cast, crew and equipment.

 

With the stretch goal of $95,000, on top of everything previously mentioned being done better (better gear, better wardrobe, and especially more and better practical effects and make up), we could have:

 

-Better fight choreography through the help of a stunt coordinator.

-Animations and sound effects for creatures one might find in a fictional post nuclear world.

-More expansive locations and film sets

-MOAR HUNTERS!

 

If we reach our basic goal of 65k, we will be able to produce independently and to keep looking for financing in order to make the series as a whole better: more professional crew members, more efficient filming, etc.

 

If we don't reach our basic goal of 65k, this is not the end of the series: we will continue to apply to other sources of financing in order to make Afterglow your next favorite series to binge.

story:
Amelia is an old lady stuck in a loop as her dementia worsens. Unable to recognize the neighbor Tom for who he really is. As Tom visits Amelia everyday hoping to be recognized, eventually reaching his limit. Will Amelia recognize Tom or will they remain stuck in the loop?

 

Amelia: An old lady (60s-70s) suffering from dementia. She is sweet, caring and lonely. Amelia is not able to recognise who the neighbour really is but she knows she has a strong connection to them.

 

Tom: A middle aged man (35-55) with a selfish desperation to be recognized by Amelia. He is caring but strict, strong but fragile and understanding but upset. Trying to remain strong but losing hope.

 

We are a group of second year Middlesex University BA Film students. We have worked together on several projects and launched our own production team - Wolfpack Productions. The inspiration for the name came with our cooperative way of working - our pack belongs together, we support each other. We are a creative and determined team who strive for our goals just  like wolves.

 

Justin Scher-Smith

Our director, Justin Scher-Smith, is an extremely committed and talented filmmaker. His short film Torn Desires had been screened at Festival de Cinema Escola de Alvorada in Brazil in 2018 and had been officially selected by 10th International Inter University Film Festival in Bangladesh.

 

 

Davide Azzalini

Davide, our producer, has an established background in cinematography. He is adventurous and likes to dream big, that’s why he is giving a shot at producing. Davide always thinks positive and is a team player which we deem great qualities for a producer to have. We put our faith in him to provide us with everything we need, and he does the same, as we aspire to excel as a pack.

 

 

Zuzanna Pencak

Zuzanna is our sound designer. With a total dedication and passion for post production, she decided to join the film course and broaden her knowledge about film at Middlesex University in London. Zuzanna has not only mastered different kinds of sound mixing software, such as Avid Pro Tools and Adobe Audition. Recording high quality content with professional gear is also nothing hard for her.

 

 

Tin Man Wu

Tin Man, our art director, learnt art and multimedia design in Hong Kong before studying film at Middlesex University in London. She is creative and passionate about her projects. She is looking forward to use her design knowledge and art skills to create outstanding and engaging visual style for our upcoming film.

 

 

The message of our film is to cherish and look after the people who looked after you. Even when diseases such as dementia and Alzheimer's can destroy the people closest in all our lives, we have to stand by them and most of all remain strong for them.

Justin worked  in a theatre that offered  classes for those with dementia and Alzheimer's. He had to be trained and taught to understand the effects of these diseases and how the most important thing people can do is help and support them with emotion, as the only thing they will remember 100% are their feelings. They may not know why they feel the way they do but they know it’s how they feel. This was something that we hadn't seen in film or many are aware of, so we wanted to bring light to this matter. Also those who are with or know someone who suffers from either of these diseases are not alone and to encourage them to keep going.

 

We aim to raise £1818 for this production. Here’s a breakdown of where your money will go:

Cast - £335

Travel - £44

Lodging - £996

Food - £220

Art Department - £55

Additional Considerations - £33

Contingency - 10%

To decrease the overall cost, we are planning to rent equipment from our university (cameras, microphones, sliders, lights, etc.).If we do not reach our goal, we will definitely get the film done no matter what. Any contribution is appreciated and it will get us one step closer to accomplish the film. If we do not reach the goal , your money  will go towards accommodation and cast .

 

What if we raise more money more than our goal ?

We will donate the excess money to  Alzheimer’s Society UK and Contented Dementia Trust. Furthermore, we might consider using them as submission fee for the London Independent Film Festival ,ŻUBROFFKA Film Festival and La Guarimba Festival.

 

 

https://www.facebook.com/uk.wolfpackproductions/

https://www.instagram.com/uk.wolfpackproductions/

You are  welcomed to follow our journey ! We will keep you posted on our progress. If you have any questions, you are welcome to direct message via Indiegogo or our social media or. If you cannot donate our film, we would be grateful for sharing this project with anyone who might be interested. Your support is really important and every bit of help matters!

 

Thank you!
