story:
If you had a way to find out how your future panned out, would you want to know?

 Hi, my name is Amanda Gordon and I am a Student Filmmaker.

When Opportunity Knocks is my senior film and with it being the last film I’ll be making in college, I want it to be the best it possibly can be! With my amazing cast, my hardworking and passionate crew and your thoughtful donation, that dream can become a reality.

When Opportunity Knocks started off as a short story I found on Tumblr. After reading the story, I feel completely in love with it and knew I wanted to turn it into a short film. After contacting the author, I was given the green light and When Opportunity Knocks was off and running. For the past 7 months, this project has been inching its way towards production. With re-writing aspects of the story, turning the story into a screenplay and figuring the in and outs of this story, I'm happy to announce that production will begin March 20th, 2019!

Garrett McKinney had no way of knowing how, but from a young age he has been able to communicate with his future self. The only catch? His future self never contacts him first. One morning Garrett’s phone goes off and it’s a text from his future self-telling him not to open the door. Just as he finishes reading the text the doorbell goes off and Garrett’s faced with whether or not to open the door. He opens the door to find 6 young girls selling cookies but it just so happens they sell him an opportunity of a lifetime.

Filmmaking has been something I’ve loved doing for over ten years now. On Christmas eve 2008, my grandmother gave me my first camera and from that moment on, my passion for making films has only grown stronger. I brought that camera to school with me and my friends and I would make short videos during recess. It’s crazy to think that those videos, launched a creative drive within me that will never diminish. With your generous donation to my film, you’re letting me know that you believe in me and support me on this crazy journey through the film industry. 

So far, my journey has taken me to Western Suffolk Boces to study film in high school, Five Towns College where I’ll be graduating with a Bachelor’s degree in Film and has brought me to 8 film festivals all over New York; allowing me to share the messages that my films have created and get a conversation started on topics that normally aren’t talked about. I’m proud of where I’ve been and what I’ve done, but I’m excited to see where I’m going.

Without you, this film wouldn’t live up to its potential. Your donation would be put towards multiple important aspects of this projects such as wardrobe, props, transportation for our actors and craft services along with so many more important things that go into making a film a success. 

Thank you for taking the time to look at my project and I look forward to putting your name in my credits soon.

story:
Short Summary of What's at Stake

Public education is one of the most important institutions in our nation and though most know that it's troubled few recognize that it is sitting on a precipice.  The steady flow of large amounts of private funds into public institutions is having a major impact in school districts around the country and brings the pressing question of who controls public schools.  More than 50 % of the nation's public school students are children of color, many from families living below the poverty level and a free quality education is often their only hope for a brighter future. That future is threatened by the shut out of parents, educators, community members and students from the policy and practice decision-making process for their schools. As the influx and influence of private funding steadily grows in local school districts the voice of the people needs  be encouraged and protected . Equity in education is a long-stated goal for the nation but democracy in education has to happen before meaningful change takes hold. Communities around the country who know and are part of the daily lives of children are fighting to increase their voices by using strategies like hunger strikes and teacher walk-outs yet many powerful politicians, corporate interests and education administrators turn a deaf ear and shut them out of the decision making process.  As we lead up to the 2020 Presidential election it's imperative that the voices of Americans in struggling communities be heard and issues important to their futures be apart of the agenda for all candidates seeking their votes.

 

Our Story
In 2010 New Jersey Governor Chris Christie and Newark Mayor Cory Booker joined Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg on the Oprah Winfrey Show in Chicago to announce an unprecedented (at the time) $100 million dollar donation to help turnaround Newark’s struggling public schools. The announcement was touted as a proposed model for the future of American schools - the influx of private funds into the public institution. Promises were made which ignited a long smoldering discontent back in Newark, who's residents had seen it all before; lots of money being made by outside groups yet little changed for the children and struggling communities in the state-run district. New Jersey is considered one of the nation's wealthiest states and it's per student spending ranks fifth among all states yet Newark, NJ's largest school district and has an annual budget near $1 billion has seen little progress since 1995 when the state took over the district and it's budget.

The "Facebook" announcement gained national attention and was applauded by many but what most peopled didn't see was it's impact;  the parents, students, teachers, school administrators and community members who were fed up with their lives being disrupted by an onslaught of chaotic policies and who fought back against the perceived big money interests and policymakers inserting their will. 

Filmmakers Ouida Washington and Derek Koen spent five years on the ground, in schools, and in the communities of Newark, NJ witnessing the rise up of local people as they responded to a school reform agenda that did not include them or even consider their input.

No! Not Without Us  is a cautionary tale about five years that changed the course of public schools. This is a story about  the impact of policies and practices that disrupt the lives of children and families across the nation and a grassroots community that empowered itself to fight back. The film seeks to uplift the voices of those on the front lines, bring awareness to what's at stake in the quest to reform public schools  and encourage civic participation in local schools by the people who are most impacted.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We began filming this project in 2011-12  following 6  students in schools selected in New Jersey's  state approved reform plan as priority schools but as their voices raised in protest to the plan our characters grew to parents, principals, teachers, and community members . We filmed through 2016  and as you may imagine we've captured a lot of footage and it took some time to meet our first challenge of honing down a story from the many we filmed that would adequately share the hard work, commitment and triumph of Newark's public school community.  Our next phase is to get a really solid rough cut of the film and we need your help to be able to bring on the best editor for the job. There are further steps in our process that go beyond the $25K we seek. If we are able to raise additional funds we will continue moving forward with the film toward completion, which includes refining the edit to a fine cut with music, sound mixing, color correction and licensing of outside footage.

In exchange for your support you will not only receive our sincere gratitude and  become a part of our online community (updates etc..)  but also receive  (based on the level of support)

Postcard of final poster w personalized note

Signed Poster

Premiere access to the film ( Includes Poster and postcards)

Thank you Credit  (Includes all of the above and credit on the film

Executive Package ( includes all of the above and a DVD copy of our previous film Beyond the Bricks)

The Impact

Filmmakers Ouida Washington and Derek  Koen were at the helm of the successful film and community engagement campaign Beyond the Bricks, which brought vital awareness to issues facing young black males in school and in their communities. Over a 2 year period The film toured over 75  cities including the UK and helped to spark a conversation and committed actions that led President Obama to the launch the White Initiative's My Brothers Keeper to address persistent opportunity gaps facing boys and young men of color. Beyond the Bricks film and discussion guides are used in universities and organizations across the country. Ouida and Derek have worked to bring attention to educational issues facing marginalized communities since 2008 and will use that track record to spur this important project forward. Please support their efforts Today!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please help us get the word out about your campaign by sharing this with friends, family and others who have a passion for equity and democracy.

story:
**If you are not located in the United States and would like to donate, please visit our GoFundMe link here.**

 

 

Story

Pathei Mathos is an experimental film that will challenge the audience’s five senses. The story, which features intrusive camera work and sound design, is divided between present day and flashbacks. It deals with the way pain is experienced and how trauma dictates the way one moves through life

The flashbacks all happen through the main character’s POV, adding a VR-like dynamic to the story and putting the audience at the forefront of the character’s experiences. For the part of the story set in the present, the quick pace of shots combined with the constant disruption of the 4th wall will challenge the audience to be participants in this experience rather than passive viewers.

 

Director's Note:

In Latin America, where I come from, disorders that don’t directly manifest themselves physically are vastly minimized and overlooked. When I began my life as an international student in the United States, a developed country, I realized that the lack of care for mental health disorders in general had no boundaries nor was it restricted to my homeland. Pathei Mathos shows a struggle which is often times invisible to society, as it represents not only the challenges of PTSD but how a survivor’s life becomes even harder when the disorder is unacknowledged.   

 

In its essence, this is a story about pain and loss, about the trauma of unexpected grief and how hurting often makes one feel broken and incomplete.

 

What We Need & What You Get

While we require a good amount of funding to make our exciting project possible, we have plenty of perks and incentives should you decide to help us out by donating! Below is a breakdown of our costs to give you a bit more background on what we need:

 

  • Camera Equipment………….....$3,000
  • Lighting…………...………….$4,400
  • Locations, permits ….................$1,000
  • Art and Makeup…..$700
  • Food & Supplies for Cast and Crew…………….….…$150

 

We have donation options of a wide variety of costs, from $5 to $100. Each donor will receive specialized incentives depending on how far up the ladder the donation is. 

 

Thank you in advance for helping our vision become a reality by donating to our campaign! We can't wait to share this special project with you all.

 

The Impact

While Post Traumatic Stress Disorder is often connected to the post-war experience when it gets portrayed on screen, Pathei Mathos aims to show the daily impact that PTSD has on the life of an ordinary girl.  

 

Only in the US, about 10% of females and 4% of males will experience PTSD at some point of their lives, which accounts for 8 million adults in one year (BrainLine.org). Although veterans make for a large portion of that number, every person is vulnerable to PTSD since it is caused by trauma (such as bullying, familial turbulence, accidents, assault of any kind). 

 

Pathei Mathos will use the tools of the cinematic art to get the audience close to the main character’s struggles, defying the line that is often used to separate audience and film to incite empathy. The VR-like cinematography as well as the change in frame rate, focus and zoom will be used to represent in an honest and raw way the traumatic flashbacks, often experienced by victims of Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.


“Pathei Mathos” is a greek term that freely translates to “from suffering knowledge”, which relates to a point of view that sees pain as a necessary step in the construction of wisdom. Although PTSD survivors have bravely been able to use the lessons they learned from their experience with the disorder to create art and help their community, Pathei Mathos focus on the difficulty of dealing with said condition without support or a full understanding of it.

 

The Team

 

Vitória Vasconcellos (Director)

Vitória Vasconcellos is a Brazilian actress and filmmaker, currently a Senior at the USC School of Cinematic Arts and an acting conservatory summer student at the Stella Adler Art of Acting Studio. She started making her own short films simply out of her desire to play more interesting characters and to tell stories that reflected the nuances of the female experience, especially that of Latina women. Ever since deciding to unite her passion for acting with her love for film, Vitória has tailored her academic curriculum with the sole goal of becoming a better storyteller (both as a filmmaker and a performer). Vitória’s work as an actor-director includes short films made in Brazil, Australia and the United States. Some of her influences include Agnès Varda, Greta Gerwig, Phoebe Waller-Bridge, Anna Muylaert, Christopher Nolan and Kleber Mendonça Filho.

 

Vasilisa Belokon (Co-producer)

Vasilisa is a current Sophomore at USC, majoring in Cinema and Media Studies with a minor in Entertainment Industry. She is natively Russian, raised in Madrid, Spain. Vasilisa has directed several short films, both narrative and documentaries. One of her most notable accomplishments was winning the award of 'best director' for one of her most recent shorts Perspicacia, or "Insight" in English, at the Cinerama Film Festival in Valladolid, Spain. Vasilisa takes great interest and hopes to build a career in directing and producing. She is passionate about telling and collaborating on stories that shed light on mental health issues and current social problems.

 

 

Erik He (Co-producer)

Erik He is an undergraduate senior studying Film and Television Production at USC. His artistic foundation stems from his upbringing, having grown up in Dubai, Montreal, New Jersey, and Malmo before moving To Los Angeles to pursue his dream in filmmaking. Erik’s focus in filmmaking is with the avant garde and extremism, with some of his biggest inspirations being the works of Alejandro Jodorowsky, Gaspar Noe, Stanley Kubrick, and David Lynch.

 

 

Hannah Kreiswirth (Co-producer)

Hannah is an incoming senior at USC's School of Cinematic Arts under the Cinema and Media Studies major. Past producing credits have included the USC Advanced Games Program project "End of the Line", where they led a team of 25 team members in creating a video game, and co producer of short film "Ivver". A huge fan of all types of media, Hannah usually spends their time reading graphic novels, playing indie video games, or going to the movies. Hannah is excited to be taking on "Pathei Mathos" as a co-producer, a new opportunity to get hands on experience in the world of experimental filmmaking. 

 

 

Orlando Pelayo (Art Director)

Orlando Pelayo moved to the U.S. from Mexico on his own as an 18-year-old to pursue a career in the film industry. He currently attends the School of Cinematic Arts at the University of Southern California where he relishes on film academia and collaborative productions. He’s a big fan of magical realism and the sci-fi genre. His favorite films are those that highlight characters’ humanity and passion. Orlando is currently developing a fashion short film titled ‘Camera Oscura’, and is spending his summer as an intern for Paramount Pictures.

 

 

Evan Siegal (1st Assistant Director)

Evan is currently a Senior in the USC School of Cinematic Arts in Los Angeles, California. Evan first took an interest in filmmaking when he was tasked to make documentary films for his high school marching band. He is currently in post production for a film he wrote and directed titled “Ivver”. The size of the production was much larger than Evan had ever dealt with before, but hard work and diligence led him to success. You can follow the final stages of the filmmaking process for Ivver on Instagram @ivver_film or on Ivver’s Facebook page! Evan is looking forward to working with Vitória and the rest of the team to make her vision come to life!

 

Risks & Challenges

Filmmaking is a difficult process, period. We don't doubt that we will overcome many hurdles on our way to making our project the best version it can be. 

Yet, we are an experienced group of creators. Each of us has worked on short films and creative projects before, and know the amount of time and work that needs to be clocked in so that we can keep the ball rolling on our project. Furthermore, each of us brings a unique specialization to our team so that we may help one another out when that time comes.

Money is perhaps the largest hurdle we need to get past as of now. We have already brainstormed some solutions if we are unable to make the amount needed for the project at first, including bake sales (we are a fine group of bakers) as well as other fun events to help raise remaining costs.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

It's quite alright if you might not have the money to help donate to our project at the moment. Just a simple shoutout on social media or a passing word to a friend will definitely help us in the long run. 

If you would like to share our fundraiser on social media, please feel free to copy our INDIEGOGO link and post it wherever on any social media platform! You can also follow and support us on our Instagram page @patheimathosfilm.

story:
What's It About?

On the eve of forced retirement, a violent hurricane traps veteran late night radio host Amy Marlowe (Caroline Williams) and her uneasy staff at WLST while her mysterious new replacement shadows her every move.

 

What is Mainframe Pictures?

Founded in 2013, Mainframe Pictures tells nostalgic stories with an edgy twist. Recent work includes:

  • Long Lost ​Currently on Prime Video's "Popular Movies" list. Also streaming on Google Play, TubiTV, YouTube Rentals, and more.
  • The Cobblestone Corridor Nationally syndicated winner of 3 New England Emmy Awards (Outstanding Director, Writer, Actor). 
  • She Came from the Woods Critically acclaimed film festival darling boasting over 20 "Best of Fest" awards.
  • Intermedium Making its west coast premiere with HollyShorts this August at the historic TCL Chinese Theaters.
  • Ghost Tour 500,000 views on CryptTV.

 

Risk Mitigation

  • Production on the film has finished and the assembly edit has been completed.
  • The team (both as a collective and individuals) boasts an impressive record of both critical and commercial success as well as project completion.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow Mainframe Pictures on the following platforms:

  • Instagram: @mainframepictures
  • Facebook: facebook.com/mainframepictures
  • Twitter: @mainframepics

story:
I am a senior at Temple University in the masterclass directing concentration. I'm currently in the works of my senior thesis film Blood and Fire. The short psychological horror/thriller follows a young family on their way home from a lake. After experiencing car trouble they must rely on the kindness of strangers, though the strangers intentions may be as far from kind as possible. 

Making a moving takes a lot of time, preparation, and hard work. But it also takes a little bit of money as well. Every penny and dime donated to our film will be used to lodge, feed, and pay our wonderful cast and crew, post production work, music rights, props, and we even have some huge film festivals we want to submit too. 

Our goal is to raise $9,000. After breaking down our script, we feel this is an adequate number to bring the script from the page to the screen in the most efficient way possible.

story:
Overview

Bulletproof Bandit follows a group of women in a dystopian world who learn that survival means nothing if you aren't living life to the fullest. 

The Story

Bulletproof Bandit follows Bandit, Mirah, and Luna in a war-torn society. Each woman has a role in their survival. Mirah is a sharpshooting leader, Bandit scavenges for supplies, and Luna is the protective caregiver. But when Luna falls deathly ill, Bandit and Mirah must take a dangerous journey to get life-saving medicine. But this journey is more than finding medicine, it is about finding a reason to live.

Why Now?

In today's society, we focus our days on getting through to the next day. We wake up, eat, work, and sleep and repeat. There is not a single person I can think of that has not had this feeling of empty survival.  This story is made to draw us out into life and find beauty in living. 

I believe that this film will make us realize that there is more to life than what we think and we only have to go out there and find our reason for living life to the fullest. 

Once we all wake up, we can truly find joy, love, and peace in a broken world. And hopefully, mend our dark world with this enlightenment.

Our Budget

Making a film is never easy but you can help make it easier by making a donation! 

Funding will directly go to creating this film in every aspect. From equipment rentals and transportation to production design and locations. 

The majority of the funds will go towards locations and transportation. We are shooting in western Massachusetts and found the perfect location. Therefore, in addition to the location fees, we will need to house and transport the crew, cast, and equipment. And not to mention, feeding our wonderful team.

We will also need funds to build the world through Production Design (PD). We also will need to have funds to ensure the best quality edit and to submit to festivals so that we will spread this message out to the world. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can always:

  • Tell others about it!
  • Share on social media!

 

Thank you all so much for reading and please consider donating today!

Sincerely, 
Madeleine

story:
The The cast and crew are humbled to have veteran character actor, Basil Hoffman, join the Rainbow Clouds film. Mr. Hoffman will utilize his honed talents to help bring the history of a family separated by misguided love to life. Basil Hoffman is an American character actor, best known for his work, often in classic films, with distinguished film directors. He is also the author of the acting textbooks, "Cold Reading and How to Be Good at It" and "Acting and How to Be Good at It" (and The Second Edition) with a foreword by Sydney Pollack. For more history of this talented performer, visit him on IMDb! We welcome you, Mr. Hoffman, to our family!

 

Summary: 

As the AIDS epidemic began; strangers become friends and learn that everyone has a story.

It began a whispered pledge and became a cry for action.

In 1985, the writer's best friend asked for a simple request: "Write my eulogy."

A difficult and heart-wrenching task, but a task done with love and respect. It took a sleepless night, countless wadded up pieces of paper and agonizing memories, but the eulogy came to life.

After reading the speech, his friend said it needed to be expanded. "It needs more. More people, more stories, more love. Everyone has a story, and those stories need to be heard."

The writer began a journey interviewing people touched by the disease. He spoke to patients in the AIDS ward at the hospital where he volunteered. He interviewed nurses, doctors, friends, family, hookers to pastors...anyone willing to share their story.

 

 

He took those personal revelations, confessions and heartache, and formed them into the stage play "Fallen Guardian Angels". Through six characters and no-holds-barred monologues, the audience enjoys a roller-coaster of emotional responses as the disease came to life in the stories of their friends and neighbors. 

The stage play evolved into the film Rainbow Clouds.

In 2019, HIV and AIDS are no longer considered a threat. The Millennial Generation knows little about the disease. Emphasis is on treatment for those infected, rather than prevention or a cure.

In Rainbow Clouds, the monologues expand to visually show the stories of these six families allowing audiences to experience their full stories, to see the pain and triumphs, to immerse themselves in the history of an unknown disease and the strain it placed on different members of society. History is notorious for swallowing up the ordinary people, and Rainbow Clouds revives their voices, reminding us that life is not always peaceful and accepting. The true heart of partiality remains, but compassion and acceptance shine through.

Rainbow Clouds is not about the government's inaction or researchers unable to decipher a riddle; Rainbow Clouds is about the people affected. How AIDS changed their lives. 

To maintain authenticity, Rainbow Clouds will be filmed entirely in Central New Mexico, mainly Albuquerque and Rio Rancho areas. 

Using the blueprint of a world-wide produced theatrical piece, Rainbow Clouds will entertain, educate and spark needed conversations. Above all, sharing the message that we must always seek hope.

To quote: Rainbows show what beauty can be when everything works together. The colors line up and, boom, a multicolored hug from the heavens.

We hope to create a loving rainbow.

Reasons to Donate or Invest! 

The Number One reason:  Movies are just really cool!

Other Reasons Include: 

Investing in local independent films can be beneficial in at least three ways. 

You can:

Be part of the increasingly exciting independent film scene, which has produced some incredibly talented homegrown filmmakers who have had their movies shown in theaters worldwide and sold their films to major TV and FILM distribution companies. Films such as The Academy-award winning “Moonlight” demonstrate that not all successful films must come from a large studio with name-talent, but that the heart of the cast and crew must remain true to the story. A strong story and empathetic cast and crew are found at the spark of all successful endeavors.

Support the local film economy and keep local talent local - changing the current cycle of losing the most talented filmmakers to other opportunities on either coast. New Mexico has talent both in front of and behind the camera. The talents are often relegated to Background players or P.A. roles by major studios. The beautiful and lush New Mexico landscape can be used for more than filming Ghost Town Westerns or another Alien Invasion epic.
What better way to prove our worth than to create a memorable film? 

25-30% state tax credit for filming in New Mexico. With the recent removal of the Caps by New Mexico government, the chance to reduce (not eliminate) some of the risk of your investment stands clear. 

The Impact

With the success of Fallen Guardian Angels as a world-wide stage production, the film, Rainbow Clouds, does have a built-in following and audience for attendance in almost all first-run cities in the U.S.A. and abroad. 

Rainbow Clouds, will help organizations and companies help raise funding for their non-profit HIV/AIDS organization. Due to the number of requests for a DVD of the stage production, we can estimate a high number of DVD purchases of the film once available.

Rainbow Clouds does not offer a possibility for sequels. There is a possibility to expand the screenplay into a 10-segment miniseries, but that is a future endeavor. However, the possibility of a major company requesting film distribution is likely.

Rainbow Clouds will be entered in various LGBT and noted Film Fests including, but not limited to: Los Angeles, San Francisco, Las Vegas, New York and New Mexico. We will also enter for consideration for inclusion with Cannes, Telluride, Toronto and various other internationally known film festivals to help increase the possibility for international distribution through a major company. 

With the recent releases of Bohemian Rhapsody. The Normal Heart and other HIV/AIDS films, interest for LGBT and HIV/AIDS material has increased on a phenomenal level. 

Our target Demographic: Employed Gay males, 18-24 yrs old. 

Although there is some disagreement about income of gay consumers compared to the average American, most sources indicate LGBT consumers have more disposable income. According to a survey done by Prudential in 2017, gay consumers reported annual household incomes around $74,500, significantly higher than the national median of just over $50,000. Gays were more likely to have higher educations, to carry less debt, to have more savings and were less likely to be jobless with an unemployment rate of almost a point below the national percentage. Additionally, LGBT homeowners in the survey had significantly more equity in their homes and were better financially set for retirement.

  • 23% higher median household income
  • 24% more equity in their homes
  • 26% of gay men say they will pay more for top quality brands
  • 30% have taken a major vacation in the past year

Estimates put the buying power of the LGBT community at over $800 billion annually. Some marketers are realizing that they may need to adjust their plans to accommodate this segment, or at least make sure that their marketing spending is inclusive of this valuable target. But many brands have been slow to pick up on the impact of the gay and lesbian consumer on their sales. We will fill in the void where LGBT consumers see a lack of fulfillment.

Risks & Challenges

Donations will help us complete our project over time, but an investment can help us finish sooner! However, an investment in a feature film is subject to a high degree of risk and is suitable only for sophisticated investors who fully understand that risk and are prepared to bear that risk for an indefinite period of time and are able to withstand a total loss of their investment.

Production Company

Asphodel Meadow Films, LLC is comprised of a committed group of professionals with an intense enthusiasm and devotion to film and other visual media, and a desire to work together to tell stories of significance. We seek to create unforgettable moments that remind others of our common humanity - to inspire, encourage, comfort, expose, challenge - and to bear witness to the reality, the beauty, the excitement and the mystery of life. We aspire to produce films that are a form of art, not merely to entertain, but to provoke emotion and reflection, incite action, and have long-lasting effects on those who experience them.

Key Personnel 

Michael Miller (Executive Producer) has been making movies for over 25 years in various capacities.  As a Producer, he’s made three feature length films, two narrative and one documentary.  He’s also produced over 25 shorts.  

His teams have won awards on many of his projects.  Prior to producing and directing film and video, he produced and directed stage shows.  Prior to entering the entertainment industry, first as an actor, he spent over 15 years in business and prior to that as an investigative journalist.

Teresa Longo (Executive Producer) is an actress who started out on stage, including as Administrative Assistant for the iconic David Bowie. She has appeared in numerous television commercials and film projects. Her teams have completed several short films. Her work in the health field has helped her organizational skills necessary for the successful completion of a feature film.  

Her talents in front of the camera are articulated in the web series “Where’s Norma Now”, where she co-wrote a few episodes. 

Edward D Padilla (Screenwriter/Director) is an accomplished author, screenwriter and playwright. His novels received numerous accolades from the LGBT community as cutting-edge and progressive, as well as being nominated for over thirty various writing awards including the prestigious LGBT Gold Coin award. Edward has been fundraising for the HIV and AIDS communities since 1985. His work earned him an honorary ambassadorship from Australia as well as many awards and recognitions. Gay/Out lists Mr. Padilla as one of the Top 25 Most Influential Gay Men in America (2010/2012). As a playwright, Mr. Padilla’s “Fallen Guardian Angels” received the seal as “Official Script of World AIDS Day” from the W.H.O. in 2013 and is mounted worldwide annually on December 1 to raise much needed funds for HIV/AIDS organizations.

story:
Hello! With the Indiegogo campaign coming to an end we would like to thank all the backers both on Indiegogo campaign and  off of it. With generous support of $900 (non Indiegogo donations) we were able to purchase a lot of equipment which will be very useful! On the the Indiegogo campaign the donations have not yet been touched as we hope to make other campaigns that will hopefully draw even more support. In the meantime funds may be used to help back other smaller short films that will help with my individual journey with film, and will also help get more attention on future campaigns for Where We Were. Feel free to contact me with any questions at liimelitevid@gmail.com 

 

About

Where We Were centers around a young woman named Anya. After her mother’s untimely death during childbirth ten years prior, she has been tasked with helping raise her younger sister, along with her aging grandparents. They live in a small seaside town. She’s known her best friend, Lillian, for her entire life, and her wannabe “boyfriend” Sean is the son of one of her late mother’s best friends. Everything about life there feels stifling for Anya. Passionate about film, she purchases a camera, and then signs up for a night class in a city a couple hours away. She begins taking a bus there a couple days a week. In the class she meets Devin. He is mysterious, and complicated, and really just the opposite of everything in her small town. He invites her to join his band, and from there her new life takes off. She becomes wrapped up in his life, it moves so much faster. Yet when Devin begins to show his true colors, and her life there begins to crumble, she’s faced again with this question; where does she really belong? 

Proof of Concept

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rC1BpKoSEgQ&feature=youtu.be

We made a short proof of concept for the film. It was low budget (almost no budget), and edited by yours truly despite the fact that is not my expertise. I wanted to be able to show donors the vision. While not dialogue heavy, it shows different moments that will be entire scenes in the full length script. We had an amazing cast and crew for the proof of concept. 

 

 

Where Will Your Donations Go?

I want to be able to compensate the actors and crew members I hire for the film. 

$6,000 will go towards compensation for actors. If we go over our goal we will be able to pay them more. 

$5,000 will go towards compensation for crew members. 

Music is very important for this story so I want to have a professional quality soundtrack. 

$1,000 will go towards music 

I’ve looked into rentals, but because we will be traveling to different locations and have a currently undetermined number of shoot days it seemed easier and most likely cheaper actually to purchase equipment. 

$4,000 will go towards equipment. 

Here is the breakdown for equipment costs. 

-Blackmagic Pocket Cinema Camera 4K $1,295

-External Monitor $150

-Juicebox Battery $119

-Cage $200 

-Samyang 85mm f/1.4 $279

-Zhiyun-Tech CRANE-M2 $269

-Tascam DR-60D MKii $188

-Audio-Technica AT875R  $169

-Movo BWS1000 Blimp Windshield and Deadcat $99.95

-Neewer Boom Pole with build in XLR audio $65.99

-XLR cables (2) $14

-Neewer LED video light $185.99

-Neewer softbox (3) $24

-Manfrotto Compact Tripod $59.99

-Manfrotto Plate $23.88

-SD cards $40

-Neewer gel set $12.99

-Wise Advanced 512GB Portable & Cinema USB 3.1 Gen 2 SSD $169

This comes out to $3,364.79

The extra $635 will be a safety net for any items I have not thought about, or price increases. 

As we will be traveling to different locations we will need money for transportation. 

$2,000 will go towards transportation. 

Since actors may not live in the Philadelphia area, and we will have shoots in other more remote locations we need to provide lodging. 

$4,000 will go towards lodging. 

The actors and crew will need to be able to eat! 

$3,000 will go towards meals.

Well done costuming and relevant props can make a film. 

$3,000 will go towards props and costumes. 

We will need to get permits to shoot places, and rent locations. 

$5,000 will go towards locations. 

Good color correction and editing software can take it to the next level. 

$2,000 will go towards editing. 

In the event of issues, it’s important to have insurance!

$1,000 will go towards insurance 

So this is a grand total of $36,000, still a small budget for a feature length film, but I have faith!

story:
Lust for revenge and regret intertwine in a female-led thriller where the hunter, cab driver Alex Baumann, becomes the prey of his passenger, influential businessman's fiancée and Dr. Sara Karim.

SARA

You don't seem to want to speak German.

ALEX

It's not that, I'm just so used to English now.

SARA

So much so that you forgot your own language?

ALEX

Well, obviously not but...

Alex looks at Sara in the rear view mirror, embarrassed.

ALEX (in German)

It's fine, we can speak German if you like.

SARA

Oh no, I don't want you to do it for me. We'll speak English. After all, your car, your rules.

 

The Story

Do human beings have a right to decide whether a person should live or die?

Sara Karim has spent three years looking for the assassin who murdered her fiancé. Finally, she has discovered his identity, a former hitman called Alex Baumann who now works as a cab driver. Now all she cares about is to kill him and get justice for her loved one and for herself. However she hasn’t considered that Alex has been there before, he has already walked down that same dark path she is about to go down in and he is there to make her reflect upon whether revenge is actually fair and legitimate and whether it is actually able to give that feeling of justice and accomplishment that forces people to commit a murder.

 

Visual Style

Cabbie is a crime film and, more specifically, a thriller. Set in one main location, Alex’ car, tension is conveyed through gripping dialogue where power constantly shifts between Alex and Sara and the roles of hunter and prey overlap. As information is revealed gradually throughout the story, the audience will experience curiosity of getting to know the characters as they try to hide their true identity to one another at the beginning and suspense about what the characters are going to do now that their intentions are clear.

The narrative device of suspense plays a huge role in keeping the spectator hooked to the screen and, visually, this goal is achieved by a painfully slow-paced kind of storytelling which keeps the audience guessing and by depicting the scenes with low-key suffused lighting that seduces, enchants and beguiles the spectator. 

 

Cast

Walaa Taha

Walaa Taha is a Palestinian actress now living in Dubai. She went from doing a part-time marketing job while pursuing her dream of becoming an actress, to modeling and acting full time. She has starred in more than 80 commercials, working with high-profile brands such as Merecedes, Waldorf Estoria Hotel, Dubai Tourism, Dove and Uber. She also kickstarted her career in TV, starring in a TV show titled Rehleh W Sayara, and in cinema, acting in films such as Tiger Zinda Hain and The Shadow of my Mom.

Christian Mandel

Christian Mandel was born and raised in Heidelberg, Germany. Early on he acted in kindergarten and school plays, not knowing that he would pursue acting until now. After graduating with a MSc in Mechanical Engineering he relocated to Abu Dhabi, UAE where he is working full time. He has acted in several TVC’s, short films and feature films. His acting credits include Star Trek 3, War Machine, Let It Go, Tiger Zinda Hai, Twisted Blues, The Click, Louder, Bharat and The Misfits.

Malavika Varadan

Malavika Varadan is a radio presenter, a Tedx speaker, a drama educator and the Managing Director of the Hive. She started learning acting at the age of 13 and believe strongly that it is storytelling that will change the world. She has acted in and directed several plays over the last 2 decades and now, at the hive, teaches over 1300 students speech and drama in Dubai. She is thrilled that the team found their perfect little girl in Saiyette and cant wait for the film to be made.

Saiyette Aima

Saiyette Aima is a student of Grade 6 at Gems Modern Academy, Dubai. Her special interests are Speech & Drama and she was the ‘UAE Topper and Subject Topper’ in the Trinity College London examination for Speech & Drama for the year 2018. For this achievement, she was specially invited to perform in the TCL Education Festival 2018. She recently played Ms. Trunchbull in the play 'Matilda' at the Junction theater Dubai. She has been a student at the Hive (a performing arts school) for the past 1 and 1/2 years.

 

Crew

Shyam Manjuvil (Director/Cinematographer)

Born and raised in Dubai, Shyam is an Architect who is currently following his passion for Cinematography and Direction. Having worked in event management for a few years, he later joined the London Film School to follow his passion. He has worked on numerous short films in different capacity spread across the globe. Cabbie is his graduation project for the London Film School.  

Sunjna Mullick (Producer)

Born and brought up in Mumbai, Sunjna pursued her Engineering before changing streams to Filmmaking. She has worked on numerous short films over the past years, in several departments, hence having a strong understanding and grasp of good collaboration. Her last short film PEAK XV  was ambitiously filmed in 2 countries and is currently in post-production. This is also her second collaboration with Shyam, who was her cinematographer for PEAK XV.

Sweta Tagliabue (Script Writer)

Born in India, raised in Italy and living in the UK. Sweta has written several short films, one of which, Crêpes, is currently circulating in the festival circuit. Her writing portfolio also includes two polished feature film screenplays, two feature film treatments, several articles about screenwriting and film making and academic writing. One of her feature films, titled Pas de deux, is currently in pre-production and the concept short film that she wrote and directed, titled Le Déjeuner, is in post-production.

Namitha Girijan (Production Designer)

Namitha Girijan, Born and raised in Dubai is currently working as an Architect since 2016.
She is a trained classical dancer and has won numerous competitions and participated in award functions. Her expertise fall in interior designing and she has a keen interest in production design.

Cmith Sarkar (Sound Recordist)

Cmith is a session musician born and raised in Dubai.  He has studied sound design and engineering, and has worked with various studios and live event managements. He has experience of being the sound recordist for various independent short films and adfilms.

Sweta Chellani (Make-up Artist)

After being a successful corporate employee, Sweta switched on to her passion of being a makeup artist. Learning never stops for her and so Prosthetic Makeup became a goal. Playing with colors and experimenting different shades is what keeps her going.

Erwick Flynn D'souza (Music Composer)

Erwick is an Indian Music Composer, Producer, Sound Designer, Pianist and Recording and Mix Engineer originally from Doha Qatar who later moved to India. There he studied Music Production and Drums from the Swarnabhoomi Academy of Music near Chennai and proceeded to score part of the Malayalam feature Film, Koode. Since then he has been working on a variety of independent Music  and Short Film Projects. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

All our funding is being used for production. The break-down being depicted below. 

We have the most unique and exciting perks, exclusively just for YOU, our supporters! Check them out!

 

Risks & Challenges

The big challenge for this production is that it is a highly ambitious project, not only for the camera department but also for the actors, who will need to carry out plenty of research about the characters’ backstories in order to portray them as real people, with their own struggles, fears, ambitions and pasts.

The theme the film revolves around is a sensitive topic that all humans can relate to. In fact, the question about whether we have a right to decide whether a person deserves to live or not is a concern that appeals to every human being, especially as the debate about whether death penalty is legitimate or not is still lively in several countries all around the world.

 After all our research and work we are confident we can talk about the theme of revenge in a compelling, fresh and thought-provoking way, but we don't want to underestimate the challenge and will always keep it in mind.

 

Why should you support Cabbie?

In a time where death penalty is considered as justice in some countries and as revenge in some others, Cabbie throws the question open whether people have a right to decide whether other human beings must live or die. Even though the answer to this question might seem quite straightforward, what would YOU do if your loved ones were murdered? Wouldn’t you give anything to track the culprit down and kill them? Wouldn’t you think that’s the only way to restore justice, both for you and for your loved ones?

By having Sara as its lead, Cabbie also casts an interesting light on the film, revisiting and reframing a genre, thriller, which usually features male leads, in an innovative way. In a time when women’s empowerment is such a sensitive topic, Cabbie tells a story of revenge and, ultimately, redemption conveying the point of view of a woman who lost her man, her husband-to-be, who watched the walls of her life crumble, and who now has the opportunity to take revenge against the person who destroyed her future. But, will she do it?

By supporting Cabbie, YOU will contribute to making an elegant Neo-Noir story come to life, while also making a difference in today's fight for women's empowerment.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Every little help matters and, if you're not in the position to support us, no worries, you can still be part of our team!

So what would you have to do?

  • Go out there and make some noise about Cabbie, share your joy about it coming to life with your family, friends, colleagues and fellow film makers!
  • To do this you just need to copy and paste the link of the campaign and the people you share it with will receive all the information they need to join our team.

If you believe in this project as much as we do, please donate, share and spread the word to everyone you can.

  • Facebook – https://www.facebook.com/Cabbieshortfilm/
  • Instagram - https://www.instagram.com/cabbieshortfilm

Every contribution will bring us a big step closer to our goal!
story_txt:
Lust for revenge and regret intertwine in a female-led thriller where the hunter, cab driver Alex Baumann, becomes the prey of his passenger, influential businessman's fiancée and Dr. Sara Karim.
SARA
You don't seem to want to speak German.
ALEX
It's not that, I'm just so used to English now.
SARA
So much so that you forgot your own language?
ALEX
Well, obviously not but...
Alex looks at Sara in the rear view mirror, embarrassed.
ALEX (in German)
It's fine, we can speak German if you like.
SARA
Oh no, I don't want you to do it for me. We'll speak English. After all, your car, your rules.

story:
Hi! My name is Heather Alison. I am 22 years old and I am a two-time cancer survivor. I am asking for your support for my senior thesis at NYU, "Great White Lies."

I first want to say thank you so much for taking interest in my film. I have been writing since I was six years old and it is incredible to finally be creating something that is so close to my heart with such an amazing team. I sincerely appreciate any contribution that is given to me for this project. You will be part of sending an important message that will hopefully make an impact on the cancer community and beyond.

My Background

In the summer of 2016, just after my 19th birthday, I found myself in a hospital room hearing the words, "You have leukemia." My life was put on hold for the next six months while I endured four rounds of chemotherapy. Exactly one year later, I relapsed, and had to spend over a year recovering from more chemotherapy and a stem cell transplant. In the photo above, I am receiving the stem cells that saved my life a little less than two years ago.

The first time I went through treatment, I immediately tried to return to my life in college like nothing had changed. I tried desperately to put everything behind me and go back to my old habits: partying, tailgating, drinking, and staying out late. I had to accept the fact that things would never be the same, and this led to an incredibly difficult journey discovering my "new normal."

The Story

"Great White Lies" is a short film about a 17 year old girl, Sofia, going to a party for the first time since she was diagnosed with cancer one year ago. Every summer, she and her best friend, Beck, throw an epic shared birthday party. Sofia gets clearance from her doctors to be able to attend this year's party, which Beck is throwing on her own. Throughout the short, she deals with many issues that are common among young adult cancer patients/survivors: body image, social anxiety, isolation, awkward questions, and broken relationships.

She struggles with the inevitable thoughts that everything would be so much easier if she'd never gotten sick. However, as she goes through the events of the film, Sofia realizes that partying with her peers is not as important as she may have once thought, and the most important thing is that she has made it to where she is today. She'll keep moving forward- like a shark.

The Impact

When I relapsed, I was added to a Facebook support group made by a few young adult patients. This group became my family. Suddenly, I saw other young adults across the country posting the exact same thoughts, questions, and jokes that were running through my head. I realized that I was not alone. In April, I flew to Colorado and I met some of these amazing people in real life.

I've heard hundreds of stories from young adult cancer patients as I've gotten more involved in the community. There are so many unique difficulties that young adult cancer patients face that are not being addressed in the mainstream media. Young adults are already in a gray area between pediatrics and adults in terms of treatment and research. We might make up a smaller demographic, but we need just as much support as these age groups.

That is why I'm looking to raise awareness about the Cancer Center for Kids (CCFK) at NYU Winthrop Hospital. Their psychosocial staff facilitates programs and events for Adolescent and Young Adult (AYA) patients. These provide opportunities for socialization and a sense of normalcy during and after treatment.

The CCFK was my second home during treatment. The doctors and nurses there treated me with exceptional care, love, and support. I am so excited to be able to connect such a personal project with the place that saved my life.

In addition, any money that isn't used for the film will be donated to the Cancer Center for Kids.

I want this film to be a voice for all of the young adult cancer patients/survivors that I've come to know and love. No cancer patient should feel like they are alone.

What Your Money Goes Towards

  • Equipment: NYU allots 500 dollars for equipment, but we are going to need a lot more than that. We want to use the right equipment that best tells this story. This also means that we will need insurance, which costs extra as well.
  • Production Design & Set Dressing: This film has a specific theme and style that has to be represented in other ways beyond just words. This includes art and set dressings, which are important for the overall look of the film.
  • Special Effects Makeup and Hair: My actress never had cancer, so we are going to need to create scars and bald caps. These are considered special effects and requires hiring somebody with training. I am also using video effects which requires hiring somebody who is trained.
  • Transportation/Food/Lodging: This film will be shot over the course of three days and we will be transporting a lot of people and equipment out to Long Island. We also need to make sure everybody is fed- The last thing you want is a hungry crew!!
  • Film Festival/Screening Fees: We want as many people to see this film as possible so that we can spread this important message.

Other Ways You Can Help

We all know someone who's had their life turned upside down by cancer.

Share this link on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, send it by email, text it to anyone who you think might support this story.

Thank you!

Thank you!

story:
Do You LINGO?

Hello! My name is Chase, I am a fresh filmmaker from Denver, Colorado.  I'm directing a short comedy about diner culture. My team and I need your support to finish this movie.

LINGO follows two American friends in the 60's who stumble into a diner full of code-talkers. Speak the language, or you go hungry.

We've assembled an outstanding group of local talent for this project. By supporting our campaign, you are encouraging independent film in Colorado and launching the dreams of my cast and crew.

The Cast

From left to right: Brandt Wintzen, Erick Yokomizo, Chaz Grundy, and Edina Loskay

What We Need

To make this baby shine, we need $4000. Your contribution will fund several elements of production, but most importantly: 

Professional post-production. Color grading, sound design, and other post production services, so that every frame stands out like a painting!

RAW FOOTAGE: 

AFTER COLOR GRADE:

You're also supporting the cast and crew. My friends are dedicated, but working for close to nothing! It's important to me that their time on set is appreciated. A portion of funding will be set aside for them.

Any additional funding over our goal allows us to submit to national festivals, bringing the movie to a screen near you.

What You Get

We've got some neat perks. We'll WRITE you, CREDIT you, heck- I'll even COOK you a meal. You can see the film on OPENING NIGHT, or PARTY with the cast at Lakeside Amusement Park. 

check 'em out on the right >

The Impact

Indie films aren't meant to stay independent. Your support brings attention to new entertainers, growing their opportunities in the film realm. You also further film in Colorado, attracting more projects to the state.

Risks & Challenges

When it comes to production, this team is outstanding. We trust our talents to execute as visual storytellers. This campaign is about the delivery. We could easily shoot a sketch comedy at the state diner with a DSLR and drop it on Youtube, but we're better than that. 

My crew has tirelessly researched and reached out to recreate the 1960's. Everything from the threads on our actor's backs to the food in the Valentine Diner fits the era. We want to stand out. Professional compositing and color set the tone, allowing reality to slip away, making the film immersive and enjoyable as possible.

We won't get into every festival, but with your support, we can bring this project to cinemas across the globe.

Other Ways You Can Help

Sharing is caring. (and considerably helpful) 

The more people who see this page the better, so please post it to your social sites and send it to your friends. Let them know you want to see this movie made!

Now's The Time

From the LINGO team, thank you for your support. We'll see you on screen.

We've assembled an outstanding group of local talent for this project. By supporting our campaign, you are encouraging independent film in Colorado and launching the dreams of my cast and crew.

The Cast



From left to right: Brandt Wintzen, Erick Yokomizo, Chaz Grundy, and Edina Loskay   What We Need To make this baby shine, we need $4000. Your contribution will fund several elements of production, but most importantly: 
Professional post-production. Color grading, sound design, and other post production services, so that every frame stands out like a painting!

RAW FOOTAGE: 

AFTER COLOR GRADE:
You're also supporting the cast and crew. My friends are dedicated, but working for close to nothing! It's important to me that their time on set is appreciated. A portion of funding will be set aside for them.

Any additional funding over our goal allows us to submit to national festivals, bringing the movie to a screen near you.



What You Get
We've got some neat perks. We'll WRITE you, CREDIT you, heck- I'll even COOK you a meal. You can see the film on OPENING NIGHT, or PARTY with the cast at Lakeside Amusement Park. 
check 'em out on the right >
The Impact Indie films aren't meant to stay independent. Your support brings attention to new entertainers, growing their opportunities in the film realm. You also further film in Colorado, attracting more projects to the state.

   Risks & Challenges When it comes to production, this team is outstanding. We trust our talents to execute as visual storytellers. This campaign is about the delivery. We could easily shoot a sketch comedy at the state diner with a DSLR and drop it on Youtube, but we're better than that. 
My crew has tirelessly researched and reached out to recreate the 1960's. Everything from the threads on our actor's backs to the food in the Valentine Diner fits the era. We want to stand out. Professional compositing and color set the tone, allowing reality to slip away, making the film immersive and enjoyable as possible.
We won't get into every festival, but with your support, we can bring this project to cinemas across the globe.   Other Ways You Can Help Sharing is caring. (and considerably helpful) 
The more people who see this page the better, so please post it to your social sites and send it to your friends. Let them know you want to see this movie made!

Now's The Time


From the LINGO team, thank you for your support. We'll see you on screen.

story:
Natural Sweetness. ZERO Sugar.

Nutritional Info (per serving):

Approx. 120 servings per bottle

  • Kcal 0.
  • Protein 0.
  • Carbs 0.
  • Sugar 0.
  • Fat 0.
  • Salt 0.

Ingredients List:

  • Sweetener: Steviol Glycosides (Stevia leaf extracts)
  • Natural Flavouring
  • Natural Preservative
  • Purified Water

6 of our favourite hand selected testimonials from consumer panel testing:


"I must say I was pretty impressed! It tasted really nice and took the bitterness off the coffee. I made my boss his usual morning tea with 3 sugars but this time I put a few drops of the liquid in and he did not notice the difference."

"This morning I used it on my porridge in place of a teaspoon of syrup and I found that really nice as it can be easily stirred in and somehow the flavours seemed to blend better and I really enjoyed my porridge and the product."

"The taste and overall effect I was looking to achieve so big thumbs up!"

"I like the design of the product especially the shape. I would also feel confident taking it out in my bag knowing that it would not leak all over my bag as is seems sturdy."

"I must say it was delicious and even the 10 year old tried a bit and gave it a thumbs up! There was no aftertaste and I am getting better at measuring the amount! Thank you for all the yummy recipes, I have never eaten so well as I have this week!"

"The joy of using stevia liquid is its so much easier to stir/mix/blend in than sugar. Really convenient and not much needed really."

Who We Are

It is widely publicised how important it is for you to cut back on your sugar intake. However, with the very naughty and not so nice sugar lurking in almost all foods, this is a task that is much easier said than done.

Unfortunately, some people are met with serious health risks and don’t have a choice on the matter. Reducing their sugar consumption, for them, is the only way to live a happy, healthy, normal life. This is exactly what happened to Modern Nature’s founder, Vanessa and is the reason why we are here today.

The idea for Modern Nature liquid stevia all started when Vanessa, discovered she had a rare blood condition. The potential implications that could arise from her blood condition were startling and she quickly learnt the best way to control it was by massively reducing the sugar intake in her diet.

This proved very difficult, however, Vanessa did find that the easiest way to tackle the issue at hand was by substituting sugar for stevia. While this was good in theory, the problem was that she needed to consume stevia in the purest way possible. Unfortunately, all the other stevia products on the market didn’t quite fit the bill. Keen to solve this problem, Vanessa set out to make her own formulation and Modern Nature’s liquid stevia was born. Always an advocate to share the sweetness and provide a solution to help others, she decided to bottle her product and bring it to the market.

Containing zero sugar, zero calories and zero artificial additives but still being full on flavour, we produce sweetness from nature. There is simply nothing else like us in the marketplace. 

“ Now is a very exciting time to be involved with all things stevia related. If there’s one thing I’ve learnt, it’s that life is sweeter when natural. I’m confident that Modern Nature will be an investment to your health and very quickly become your new favourite thing, just like it did mine”.

Vanessa Rollins, CEO

Our Vision for Modern Nature

We are on a mission to help make the transition for adopting and following the much needed low-sugar/ no-sugar lifestyle a healthy and enjoyable one. We can’t do that, however, without your help and support to make the product available for purchase.

We are raising $15, 000 to help us increase our stock, start our production run, and expand our Modern Nature family to allow us to bring you our product on a faster timescale and build a new website.

Your support will help fund:

  • Increasing our stock
  • Starting production
  • New employment
  • New website

What's up for grabs?

  • The star of the show - Modern Nature Liquid Stevia
  • Information to help you get started enjoying Modern Nature
  • Measuring spoons
  • Delicious recipe cards which are specifically tailored to Modern Nature Liquid Stevia

We are extremely passionate about providing Modern Nature to everyone on a global scale in order to do our bit to help combat the existing and fast growing sugar problem.

From feedback of the few who have tested our product, everyone loves it and provided us with an immensely positive response. We have also been deemed the ones to watch in our local start-up community. This is something we are very proud of.

Risks & Challenges

Our sweet aspiration is to be the answer for many people struggling to shake off sugar, and need your help in making our product available on a mass scale.

To set ourselves up for success, we are reaching out to you and establishing a community that believes in our vision as much as we do. We have a strong support system behind us in our mentors who work with us regularly to help make this dream a reality.

Other Ways You Can Help

Our product is totally exclusive to Indiegogo at present, so for the time being this is the only place were you will be able to get your hands on one. However, there are many other ways to contribute to our campaign. Any of the following options would greatly benefit our chances of achieving or even surpassing our goal of $15, 000 dollars:

  • A direct contribution to the campaign
  • Joining our social community to help us introduce naturally tasty sweetness
  • Spreading our message to your social media pages to inspire others to contribute
  • Telling your family, friends and network about Modern Nature

We can’t thank you enough for your sweet support. If there’s one thing we’ve learnt, it’s that life is sweeter when natural. We are certain that Modern Nature liquid stevia will be an investment to your health as a little goes a very long way. We're so excited to bring it to you and hope you fall in love with it as much as we have!

story:
Desolation Angels/Rise of the BOAS is a movie based on the Morality Issues raised in Classical Greek mythology. The question continues to haunt man: Are we able to change our fate or is life predestined by the gods?

  In DA/ROTB a group of mercenaries are hired by a covert government agency to disrupt the relationship between the Russian mob and the Mexican drug cartels.

  The BOAS are a group of highly trained,ex-military contractors who work for whomever pays. In this case it’s the higher- ups of a shadow government.

  Some BOAS have normal jobs, or pretend to at face value. They have no moral code; in general they like what they have been trained to do. The thought of killing anyone is not an issue they even ponder.

  Along the way, a few try to change their fate without success.

  Their Russian adversaries are ruthless and care nothing for human life. They care only about maximizing profits from their lucrative drug trade.

  The head of the Russian mob, Yury, has no qualms about using excessive force to persuade those in his path to comply. Unfortunately the BOAS adopt his satanically driven methods.

 The result is not a fight between good and evil but rather a battle between evil and evil.

 The movie is old style B&W and is 90 minutes in length.

  We are asking for donations on Indegodo to help us edit this project, a labor of love for the 50 actors involved

The production was filmed entirely in Fairfield and New Haven counties in the state of Connecticut.

  Our plan is to enter the film in festivals to gain recognition for a talented group of actors et.al.  And gain industry awareness ,so we’ll be able to shoot another new, conceptually different movie in the future..

story:
A Journey for Justice

“A Journey for Justice” is a project to bring our delegation of activists from India along with the documentary "CHAR.. the No Man's Island" to the International Festival of Cinema and Human Rights in Europe. Two activists, a human rights expert and a coordinator will be traveling from India to Italy to discuss the human rights issues relative to landless people in India.                                                 


“Between 60 and 65 million people are estimated to have been displaced in India since Independence, the highest number of people uprooted for development projects in the world. This amounts to around one million displaced every year since Independence. At same time environmental resources are being openly destroyed on a colossal scale in search for endless economic growth.”

Since 1990, in the name of development, India has started to to transfer resources from the poor to politically and economically powerful groups. This has forced thousands of people leaving their home and their life, to become homeless. If this is development, ask the displaced, why don’t we benefit from it? And why does it irreparably destroy the natural environment?

While we speak of India, globally over 60% of people forced out of their homes are victims of internal displacement. Of the 43 million people forced to flee their homes, 26 million are displaced within their own country, 16 million are refugees and one million are asylum-seekers.



THE FESTIVAL 

With this journey, we will bring the documentary "CHAR.. The No Man Island" and the testimony of our experts closely working with the people movements in India to the Festival of Cinema and Human Rights in Europe. The festival supported by Amnesty International will be hold in Italy from 9 to 14 November, 2015. (http://www.humanrightsfilmnetwork.org/festivals/festival-del-cinema-dei-diritti-umani-di-napoli).

The International Festival of Human Rights and Cinema acts as a platform for the filmmakers around the world to project and promote excellence, beside providing a unique opportunity to discuss on theme and issues which are otherwise unnoticed. 

The Naples Human Rights Film Festival is an international event which began in 2008 and that is both promoted and coordinated by the “Cinema e Diritti” (Cinema and Human Rights) Association using a self-managed and participatory formula.  The objective of the event is to promote the theme of Human Rights and to contribute towards correct and plural sources of information regarding the living conditions of the most discriminated social categories, by providing, through cinema and meetings with authors and witnesses, options for further reflection relating to ongoing global transformations. 

http://www.cinenapolidiritti.it/web/en/2015/09/...

THIS JOURNEY FROM INDIA TO ITALY,  accompanied by the documentary of Saurav Saurangi, is to share the voices of the most oppressed groups of India. To strengthen solidarity and support for thousands of people who are losing access and control over their own natural resources, their lives and their livelihoods.


THE DOCUMENTARY 

The discussion will be introduced by the expressive images of Sourav Sarangi’s documentary “CHAR.. The No Man’s island” (2009), a film distributed in Italy by Stefilm ( www.stefilm.it or  https://www.facebook.com/stefilminternational?fref=ts).

The documentary reflects on the aftermath of The Farakka Barrage built in 1975. The barrage was constructed across the river Ganga in West Bengal and changed the river Ganga’s flow, by creating transient islands or ‘chars’. The ‘Chars’ emerged like a gift that the river gave to the people as a refuge after it tore away their native village when the water levels rose. Sauragi’s points out how even the Nature has neither sympathy nor understanding for the vulnerable communities living at the borders, showing the fragility and the struggle of these people throughout the eyes of a 15years old boy. 

Taking forward from the documentary the session will focus on the exploitation of land and citizens, who represent the most marginalized and excluded section of the society; their persistence in finding new solution, their stories of hope and change will be the argument of the discussion. From natural disaster to actual land grabbing, the session will discuss and bring on the same table some examples of struggle happening in the state and in surroundings.

What do we do with the money?

We need your help to make this project happening, and to ensure the screening of the movie at the festival! This is to create awareness on the struggle of people and on the unnoticed conflicts and dilemma happening in India!

We are already on the final program of the festival, and our friends in Naples are waiting for us! We cannot miss the opportunity to screen this important documentary and give voice to the thousands of landless people of India! We are already working hard, and many are supporting this activity.

But we need YOUR help to cover the following costs:

  • Travel of 2 activists, 1 coordinator and 1 organizer
  • expenses in loco ( accommodation, food, etc.) 
  • release of documents pre and post festival 
  • organization of the post Mini Festival on Human Rights in Delhi in 2016
  • editor rights for the screening of the movie "CHAR.. The No Man Island"

If you cannot donate money, don’t worry, you can still help us! Please share this appeal on your Facebook page, twitter and other social networks and help us reach our goal of building peace and justice for the marginalized!


NON-PROFIT PARTNERS:

CINEMA e DIRITTI

http://www.cinemaediritti.org/home/?lang=it

The “Cinema e Diritti” (Cinema and Human Rights) cultural association was founded in 2005 and is based in Salerno (Italy). It is a non-profit association and initiated, it coordinates and promotes the Naples Human Rights Film Festival. The “Cinema e Diritti” (Cinema and Human Rights) cultural association proposes a modern idea of socially-responsible films, paying particular attention to the social transformations of the globalised world, keeping one eye on the living conditions of the poor countries and another on the urban outskirts of the West, always focusing on stories of resistance and hope to be told to youngsters, in schools and universities, described with the expressive force of the language of cinema. Its ambition is to make Naples, by means of this Festival, a place where to meet and hold debates on the theme of democracy, in short, one of the World Capitals of Human Rights.

KRITI FILM CLUB

http://krititeam.blogspot.in/

Kriti Film Club is an educational and research oriented initiative of Kriti: a development research, praxis and communication team. We offer an independent and informal space for screening documentary films on a whole range of development, human rights & environment issues. We also serve as an access space for documentary films, development and human rights literature and other resistance resources. We network closely with struggles for social justice and peace.

SRUTI

http://www.sruti.org.in/

Society for Rural Urban and Tribal Initiative, established in 1983, is a not-for-profit organisation that works towards social change at the grass roots, across rural and urban India, through its Fellowship Programme. It is committed to empowering marginalized people to lead a dignified life with access to livelihood, resources, rights and justice.
