story:
FIRST (STORY):

You can read the script here. 

 

SECOND (PITCH): 

The pitch video is über short because some people only need the meat and potatoes. However, if you want the full, 22-page treatment on the film's tone, picture, editing, timeline, budget, crew, and the whole enchilada, then you can read the fully-loaded, super-detailed treatment for this project here OR scroll down below to see selected parts of it.

 

THIRD (FUNDS):

We've already raised funds for the ambulance, EMT's, police cars, uniforms, and food for 3.5 days of shooting. We're now raising funds for the cast, crew, locations, & temporary equipment insurance - if we fall short on this goal here on Indiegogo, we'll make up the balance with outside investors. 

 

FULL RUNDOWN

 

Much of the first 11-12 minutes of this noirish pilot takes place at night. Visually, it will involve a lot of dark (pitch black) and muted art direction as our heroine, Joy Malcolm (30’s, single), is an ex-Air Force medic battling through PTSD. She is desensitized to matters of life and death due to experiences during her overseas war zone tours

As this is a pilot, the antagonist Baal (40’s - 50’s) will be introduced early on, and he represents darkness in the town and in the story. He always wears a 3-piece suit, has a morbid sense of humor, always carries a newspaper, and employs a large group of fallen angels who are equally muted and devoid of light.

On the other hand, Joy does encounter the archangel Michael in the first 12 minutes, and he is in every sense of the word the antithesis of the antagonist. His upbeat outlook is the lone source of optimism in Joy’s rundown world.

Colors will be mostly dark, muted, and even light sources will be green/blue to strip the viewer of any sense of warmth.

 

 

 

We’re going to shoot for 42 hours, spread across 3.5 days to have ample coverage of the 11-12 minutes. While each scene builds on the previous scene as Joy sequentially discovers her gift, the pacing of this story closely follows that of a Sergio Leone spaghetti western: slow, with long takes, sparse dialogue, and wide shots to allow the environment to build tension. This is intentional, to underscore the muted and dark tonality of Joy’s world.

I shoot for the edit since I will do the editing myself. From the moment I step on location, I’m ready to go with a detailed battle plan to squeeze the most out of our shoot times. With rare, isolated exceptions, my teams do not go over shoot times and we manage to get all of our coverage.

 

 

Visually, I’d like to approach this story with an abundance of traditional, locked down cinematography. We’ll use sliders and dollies to follow movement, but like an older film from 50 years ago, a substantial amount of the story will be told through medium and wide shots with the camera locked down on its tripod, to further accentuate the feeling of being isolated, alone, and disconnected from the world (the viewer).

I typically like to keep my cameras moving with the characters in the scene, going in for the close-ups so that we are connected to our characters and absorbed in their world, building on that need for human interaction that we’re wired for. With this pilot, we will not do that. It’s paramount that we shy away from close-ups to accentuate the feeling of isolation. Lighting-wise, I like the use of natural lighting (e.g. from a window) and practical lighting already existing in our environments. This minimalistic approach avoids the canned or scripted look - we’re going for naturalism here. I’ll aim to shoot in the afternoon to avoid rapidly changing shadows and at night. Everything will be shot practically with the occasional touchup of a digital wand during the editing process.

 

 

These dynamics are understated in film and video. They work in tandem to create the atmosphere we so desire. We can build tension with a subtle bassline that swells into a big cinematic piece, but then we can switch the mood a bit with softer string sections. Our sonic experience will keep viewers guessing and engaged - not entirely certain what will happen next.

The soundtrack will be mostly made up of diegetic sounds. In this regard, the modern Western “No Country for Old Men” is an excellent reference. At other times, the pilot will use music that does not fit the genre. This is intentional to avoid cliche moments and tropes. The soundtrack rather is more about the main character Joy, and the emotions she experiences. It is less about building suspense (though there will be those moments) because in the moments where suspense is required or where the tension needs to build, the music will drop out a la the aforementioned Western.

 

  • Actors (10 featured roles, 34 extras)  → $5,458.75
  • Locations → $1,285.00
  • Crew (Cinematographer, AD, Location Manager, Grip, Sound Operator) → $6,010.00
  • Indiegogo/Credit Card Fees → $1,146.84
  • Temporary Equipment Insurance → $434.95

 

 

The initial story came about summer of 2016, with the script following soon afterward. Gathering the crew and storyboarding began fall of 2016. Script revisions and peer reviews took place this past winter and currently we are in the fundraising process.

Production starts on April 28th and runs through April 30th. There is a break before production resumes on May 5th and concludes on May 7th. It will be shot locally in Las Vegas, and all post-production will take place here in Las Vegas as well.

Because of my years of doing corporate work, I know that I can turn this 11-minute film around very quickly. Music is minimal, the film is following its storyboard closely, and we are working with a team that’s geared for efficiency. Editing will be quick. Once production concludes on May 7th, I estimate that by June 26th, this film will be completed and already making its rounds in front of the decision-makers and influencers at our principal video-on-demand platforms: Amazon and Netflix.

 

 

Producer/Director/Writer/Editor - Jake Keenum

I want to encourage others and bring honor to the Almighty in everything that I do with film and video. I believe it is our responsibility to share the message of hope, unconditional love, and forgiveness through media and do it in a way that is engaging, not self-serving, and not campy (take your pick, there are lots of bad apples - my favorite example of what TO DO is the 1998 Les Miserables directed by Billie August, and it was not marketed as faith-based... clever. It's just a story of a man who found redemption and grace but still struggles with forgiveness).

I shot my first super microbudget feature “12 Til Dusk” in 2013 in SLC, UT. We finished on time, with zero accidents, and released it on YouTube in 2014. In 2015, I started my business and served Las Vegas businesses through video production, even producing, directing, and budgeting 4- and 5-figure shoots from cradle to grave.

Visual/Director Reel: churchfilms.com/reel

 

DP/Cinematographer - Justin Melson 

Justin is a filmmaker and director of photography for Happyfox Productions. Justin first started filmmaking in middle school and continues to pursue filmmaking as a career path. Justin has worked on over a dozen short films as a cinematographer/colorist and has received over 2.5 million views online.

Additionally, Justin has produced televisions shows and videos for various celebrity figures and television networks such as Floyd Mayweather, Las Vegas Mayor Goodman, Andre Agassi, FOX Sports, and NBC.

Visual/Director Reel: churchfilms.com/justin

 

Who else is on the team?

  • Assistant Director - Ashley Piper
  • Casting Director - Shalom Keenum
  • Location Manager - Kim Donohue
  • Sound Operator - Carlos Hernandez
  • Grip - Radames Eliu


THANK YOU

Additional questions? Call the office at 702-907-0220.

His upbeat outlook is the lone source of optimism in Joy’s rundown world.Colors will be mostly dark, muted, and even light sources will be green/blue to strip the viewer of any sense of warmth.   We’re going to shoot for 42 hours, spread across 3.5 days to have ample coverage of the 11-12 minutes. While each scene builds on the previous scene as Joy sequentially discovers her gift, the pacing of this story closely follows that of a Sergio Leone spaghetti western: slow, with long takes, sparse dialogue, and wide shots to allow the environment to build tension. This is intentional, to underscore the muted and dark tonality of Joy’s world.I shoot for the edit since I will do the editing myself. From the moment I step on location, I’m ready to go with a detailed battle plan to squeeze the most out of our shoot times. With rare, isolated exceptions, my teams do not go over shoot times and we manage to get all of our coverage.  Visually, I’d like to approach this story with an abundance of traditional, locked down cinematography. We’ll use sliders and dollies to follow movement, but like an older film from 50 years ago, a substantial amount of the story will be told through medium and wide shots with the camera locked down on its tripod, to further accentuate the feeling of being isolated, alone, and disconnected from the world (the viewer).I typically like to keep my cameras moving with the characters in the scene, going in for the close-ups so that we are connected to our characters and absorbed in their world, building on that need for human interaction that we’re wired for. With this pilot, we will not do that. It’s paramount that we shy away from close-ups to accentuate the feeling of isolation. Lighting-wise, I like the use of natural lighting (e.g. from a window) and practical lighting already existing in our environments. This minimalistic approach avoids the canned or scripted look - we’re going for naturalism here. I’ll aim to shoot in the afternoon to avoid rapidly changing shadows and at night. Everything will be shot practically with the occasional touchup of a digital wand during the editing process.  These dynamics are understated in film and video. They work in tandem to create the atmosphere we so desire. We can build tension with a subtle bassline that swells into a big cinematic piece, but then we can switch the mood a bit with softer string sections. Our sonic experience will keep viewers guessing and engaged - not entirely certain what will happen next.The soundtrack will be mostly made up of diegetic sounds. In this regard, the modern Western “No Country for Old Men” is an excellent reference. At other times, the pilot will use music that does not fit the genre. This is intentional to avoid cliche moments and tropes. The soundtrack rather is more about the main character Joy, and the emotions she experiences. It is less about building suspense (though there will be those moments) because in the moments where suspense is required or where the tension needs to build, the music will drop out a la the aforementioned Western. 
Actors (10 featured roles, 34 extras)  → $5,458.75
Locations → $1,285.00
Crew (Cinematographer, AD, Location Manager, Grip, Sound Operator) → $6,010.00
Indiegogo/Credit Card Fees → $1,146.84
Temporary Equipment Insurance → $434.95
  The initial story came about summer of 2016, with the script following soon afterward. Gathering the crew and storyboarding began fall of 2016. Script revisions and peer reviews took place this past winter and currently we are in the fundraising process.Production starts on April 28th and runs through April 30th. There is a break before production resumes on May 5th and concludes on May 7th. It will be shot locally in Las Vegas, and all post-production will take place here in Las Vegas as well.Because of my years of doing corporate work, I know that I can turn this 11-minute film around very quickly. Music is minimal, the film is following its storyboard closely, and we are working with a team that’s geared for efficiency. Editing will be quick. Once production concludes on May 7th, I estimate that by June 26th, this film will be completed and already making its rounds in front of the decision-makers and influencers at our principal video-on-demand platforms: Amazon and Netflix.  Producer/Director/Writer/Editor - Jake KeenumI want to encourage others and bring honor to the Almighty in everything that I do with film and video. I believe it is our responsibility to share the message of hope, unconditional love, and forgiveness through media and do it in a way that is engaging, not self-serving, and not campy (take your pick, there are lots of bad apples - my favorite example of what TO DO is the 1998 Les Miserables directed by Billie August, and it was not marketed as faith-based... clever. It's just a story of a man who found redemption and grace but still struggles with forgiveness).I shot my first super microbudget feature “12 Til Dusk” in 2013 in SLC, UT. We finished on time, with zero accidents, and released it on YouTube in 2014. In 2015, I started my business and served Las Vegas businesses through video production, even producing, directing, and budgeting 4- and 5-figure shoots from cradle to grave.Visual/Director Reel: churchfilms.com/reel DP/Cinematographer - Justin Melson Justin is a filmmaker and director of photography for Happyfox Productions. Justin first started filmmaking in middle school and continues to pursue filmmaking as a career path. Justin has worked on over a dozen short films as a cinematographer/colorist and has received over 2.5 million views online.Additionally, Justin has produced televisions shows and videos for various celebrity figures and television networks such as Floyd Mayweather, Las Vegas Mayor Goodman, Andre Agassi, FOX Sports, and NBC.Visual/Director Reel: churchfilms.com/justin Who else is on the team?
Assistant Director - Ashley Piper
Casting Director - Shalom Keenum
Location Manager - Kim Donohue
Sound Operator - Carlos Hernandez
Grip - Radames Eliu

THANK YOUAdditional questions? Call the office at 702-907-0220.

story:
Currently we are financing this project through Indiegogo with a goal of $900, and Kickstarter with a goal of $6000. Cost will go towards staff, crew, talent, and production necessities. The goal is to produce a professional quality film - giving organizations a talking piece, festivals something worthy of presenting, and viewers to enjoy. 

 

Every contribution will help us get closer to making AUTISTIC AMERICA a reality. Pre-Production scheduled in May, Production in June, Post completed by late June.

Pre-Production scheduled in May, Production in June, Post completed by late June.

story:
Dear Supporters and Friends,

We are excited to announce that after more than 2 years of work we are close to finishing our documentary film and now we need your help and financial support in order to complete it.

Thank you for your consideration and donations.

This is a story about an 83 year-old man who decided to participate in the Bar Mitzvah he missed 70 years ago because history obstructed his path. He meets a rabbi when the rabbi’s teenage son is getting ready for Bar Mitzvah. The old man and young boy go through the learning and preparation together. But it means something very different for them both…

During their practices Gyuri starts to allow himself to remember and talk about the things he kept as a secret for 70 years. He recalls the eve of his own passage to manhood, when he joined the millions of others who entered the gates of Auschwitz. Luckily, Gyuri was strong and tall for his age, and he followed the advice of the first man he met in the crowded wagon: he had to tell the Nazis that he was 15 and not 13, thus being able to join an adult working group and not the queue for the gas chambers where most children of his age would go. Somehow, he survived and managed to get back home to Budapest. The rabbi’s son, Shalom, an innocent 13 year old boy, is full of dreams and hopes, and reminds Gyuri of his lost childhood. When the rabbi and the child allow the old man to experience the ritual of their everyday lives they somehow introduce him to an alternative universe - a world which could have been his - if only history could have taken another course.

 

OUR MISSION

Our film is meant to be timely and relevant because the world is not getting any better in 2017. People are very much in need of finding micro communities to enhance the quality of their lives. By using humor we hope our viewers will laugh and yet feel the heavy sense of loss and redemption. The tragedy of Gyuri is in the past, yet life and love goes on around him and becomes central to his own existence - and shows how life and love will always triumph. It is never too late for anyone, no matter how badly scarred or damaged they are, to open his or her own heart and mind.

 

DIRECTOR'S NOTE

I am very much dedicated to making films against prejudice. During the process of pulling this film together I discovered I was on my own personal and spiritual journey as well. This work is helping me to reconnect with my own roots, my culture, my spirituality and self-identity. I am passionate about this coming-of-age story because I want my viewers to understand and feel empathy for the torture this old man has had to carry in his heart and soul throughout his life. It is my hope that this story we witness together might change his and our own lives. My intention is to show how family relationships and maintaining a dialogue between generations are essential to the human existence.

Director, Kata Olah

 

MEET OUR TEAM

I am Kata Olah, the director of this film. I have worked in the film industry for over 20 years in different capacities, mainly as a producer. Fulfilling my own childhood dream, I started to focus on directing few years ago.  This will be is my first feature-length documentary film and one that holds my passion. My first short fiction, En Passant was screened at several international festivals and won numerous awards. I always work together with my husband, an acknowledged cinematographer.

Sándor Csukás was the cinematographer for more than 12 feature films, numerous Television series short films and documentaries. He was elected to be The cinematographer of the year 2011 in Hungary, won Best Cinematographer Award in the documentary film section at National Film Week of Hungary for four times and also holds the prestigious Bela Balazs Prize.

Rest of the team consists of 2 young talented ladies. One of them Katalin Egely, she is responsible for the animation of our film. She is a great talent who graduated from the animation department of Moholy-Nagy University of Art and Design Budapest, Hungary (MOME).  Ever since she has been working as a freelance animator.

The other is Patricia D’Intino, an emerging producer, who joined our team to help the final phases of production and post-production and the afterlife of the film. She has a solid production background as she was as an assistant producer and co-ordinator at one of the leading Hungarian service producing companies. Besides she is also developing her first feature and animation project and supports new-coming directors.

And finally we should not forget about Gergely Barcza, who is composing an original music for us! Gergely is a very talented composer and the lead musician of a very popular band in Hungary, the Besh o droM. 

 

HOW YOUR MONEY WILL BE SPENT

The funding we receive will go to two main sections: post-production and promotion-distribution. For over two years we filmed with uncle Gyuri and teenager Shalom because we believed in the potential to tell a unique and powerful story. We put a large self investment into making this film.Your money will be put towards a number of essential elements that will help to complete this film and tell this special story the vivid way it should be told. Postproduction: editing, sound and color grading on a feature documentary film over this length of time needs time and money. This will be achieved to the highest standards with your potential help. Hand drawing animation is also an essential ingredient. We wish to screen our film as widely as possible at international film festivals and hope to reach an audience all over the world.

10% of the raised money will be dedicated to support the reconstruction works still in progress at the Óbuda Synagogue, Budapest.

https://obudaizsinagoga.hu/.

This is the venue where our protagonist's dream eventually came true. 

 

What exactly do we need the money for?

 

WHAT YOU CAN DO

Please share this campaign with as many friends and family as possible through e-mail and social media using the Indiegogo share tools. The Bar Mitzvah boys will be completed by the end of this year with your help and we are proud to offer you these very personal rewards to say thank you for joining us on this journey along with our protagonists and team.

Thank you!

story:
My Story & Now Yours

In this gripping and haunting short film, the mysterious disappearance of a young girl sends shockwaves through the teens of a small neighborhood.  This story explores youth in all of its forms.  The invincibility of youth.  The imagination of youth.  The tragedy of youth.  Join us in making this story a reality!

 

Budget - $2,500

Production: $500

In order to make movie magic, we invest a lot of time in making our set look as best as possible. This includes making our environment and characters look unique and realistic. We need your help to make this possible!  Big essentials on sets are coffee, trash bags, and especially hand warmers since it’s Upstate New York.  All in all, this money will be going towards wardrobe, props, and everyday production essentials.  Please help keep our crew energized and warm!

Effects: $200

To dish out the sci-fi/horror look to the film, we need to acquire effects materials! That includes smoke machines, makeup, gas, eye drops, and a multitude of other things.

Food: $1,200

Keeping the crew fed is important! Working mostly at night, our actors and crew members will tough it out in negative-degree weather in the middle of the winter. They do love a good cup of soup, so your donation helps us provide it for them!

Insurance and Transportation: $600

Film equipment is very expensive and even more fragile. Film sets are very unpredictable, especially with the crazy weather in Upstate New York, so keeping the film equipment secure in any dangerous situation is always important. We also need to store all of the equipment in a truck and help get our crew to locations.  Without transportation, we can’t shoot (Gasp!).

 

The Impact

This particular story is very close to our hearts, as we have all gone through the trials of youth. My main goal for this film is to explore what it means to be young, and how youth reacts to unexpected trials. This film is aimed to speak to the audience on an intimate level as we attempt to understand loss at a young age.

 

Risks & Challenges

Starry-Eyed requires a lot of equipment, therefore transporting and storing everything will be difficult.  We plan on using part of the budget to rent a U-Haul in order to bring equipment to our locations.  

As you may know, February in Syracuse is an extremely bitter month.  We will be facing obstacles having to do with freezing temperatures, as a lot of the film takes place outside.  Layers, hand warmers, and frozen noses will be the norm during the shooting days.  We will be shooting for 6 days over two consecutive weekends.  It will certainly be a grind, but we will do it with pride.  At the end of this fundraiser, if we don’t receive enough money, creating this film will be a challenge. With your help, we can make this project possible.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If donating money just isn’t in the cards for you right now, a share on your page to make some noise helps too!  Help us get the word out in any way possible.  Tweet, post, share, and use the Indiegogo share tools on the website.  Thank you to anyone who can contribute with either a donation or your voice, you are making our dreams come true!
